src_legal: Where, as here, a prisoner “challenges the very fact or duration of his physical imprisonment, and the relief he seeks is a determination that he is entitled to immediate release or a speedier release from that imprisonment, his sole federal remedy is a writ of habeas corpus.” Preiser v. Rodriguez, 411 U.S. 475, 500, 93 S.Ct.

src_legal: Unclean hands “is a self-imposed ordinance that closes the doors of a court of equity to one tainted with inequitableness or bad faith relative to the matter in which he seeks relief’ and originates from “the equitable maxim that ‘he who comes into equity must come with clean hands.’ ” Precision Instrument Mfg.
tgt_plain: Unclean hands is a self-imposed principle that prevents someone involved in a matter from seeking relief in a court of equity if they have acted unfairly or in bad faith. This principle originates from the saying, "he who comes into equity must come with clean hands."

src_legal: First, the court must “tak[e] note of the elements a plaintiff must plead to state a claim.” Second, the court should identify allegations that, “because they are no more than conclusions, are not entitled to the assumption of truth.” Finally, “where there are well-pleaded factual allegations, a court should assume their veracity and then determine whether they plausibly give rise to an entitlement for relief.”
tgt_plain: First, the court must examine the elements of a claim. Second, the court should identify claims that are no more than conclusions, which cannot be assumed as true. Finally, the court should assume the accuracy of well-defended claims, and determine whether they reasonably give rise to an entitlement for relief.

src_legal: He alleged three federal claims: (1) that the defendants, acting individually, jointly, and in conspiracy, deprived Beaman of a fair trial by withholding material exculpatory evidence in violation of Brady (individual liability); (2) that the defendants conspired to deprive Beaman of material exculpatory evidence (conspiracy liability); and (3) that the defendants failed to intervene in preventing the violation of his rights (failure to intervene liability).
tgt_plain: He alleged three federal claims. The first claim is that the defendants, acting individually, jointly, and in conspiracy, deprived Beaman of a fair trial by hiding evidence, which could be used to prove Brady’s claims case (individual liability). The second claim is that the defendants conspired to deprive Beaman of evidence that could be used to prove Beaman’s case(conspiracy liability). The third claim is that the defendants should have prevented the violation of his rights but did not (failure to intervene liability).

src_legal: Given the holding in Koloms, the question remaining for the Court, then, is whether the underlying suits are like the furnace leak in Koloms, namely, the type of isolated, run-of-the-mill result from day-to-day operations and properly covered, or whether they arise from “traditional environmental pollution.” Though it may be more art than science to determine when the isolated consequences of normal business operations end and “traditional environmental pollution” begins, the instant case falls cleanly within the definition.

src_legal: Works Co. are: (1) the defendant's good faith effort to comply with the statute: (2) the defendant's degree of culpability; (3) the defendant’s histoiy of previous violations; (4) the nature of the public interest in ensuring compliance with the regulations involved; (5) the nature and circumstances of the violation at issue; (6) the gravity of the violation; (7) the defendant’s ability to pay; (8) the appropriateness of the size of the penalty to the defendant’s business and the effect of a penalty on the defendant’s ability to continue doing business; (9) that the penalty not otherwise be shocking to the conscious of the court; (10) the economic benefit gained by the defendant through the violation; (11) the degree of harm to the public; (12) the value of vindicating the agency authority; (13) whether the party sought to be protected by the statute had been adequately compensated for the harm; and (14) such other matters as justice may require.
tgt_plain: Works Co. are: (1) the defendant's good faith effort to comply with the statute: (2) the defendant's degree of fault; (3) the defendant’s history of previous violations; (4) the nature of the public interest in ensuring compliance with the regulations involved; (5) the nature and circumstances of the violation at issue; (6) the seriousness of the violation; (7) the defendant’s ability to pay; (8) the appropriateness of the size of the penalty to the defendant’s business and the effect of a penalty on the defendant’s ability to continue doing business; (9) that the penalty not otherwise be highly unjust to the observer; (10) the economic benefit gained by the defendant through the violation; (11) the degree of harm to the public; (12) the value of clearing the agency authority of blame; (13) whether the party sought to be protected by the statute had been adequately compensated for the harm; and (14) such other matters as justice may require.

src_legal: In his claim for negligence, Plaintiff alleges that Defendant NDI’s potentially negligent conduct includes: (1) failing to ensure a proper chain of custody of the subject specimen; (2) failing to communicate with Plaintiff and the testing facilities any and all factors which could or did affect the testing; (3) failing to take into account and eliminate any and all factors which may improperly influence the tests; (4) failing to prevent testing results of and/or reporting of a “false-positive”; (5) failing to pre-test interview Plaintiff to rule out abnormalities which could and/or did influence the tests; (5) failing to maintain and/or cause to be maintained appropriate quality-control testing and/or reporting mechanisms and/or protocols; (6) failing to comply with governing procedures, regulations, protocols, and/or laws concerning reporting and/or testing; and (7) failing to monitor and/or control others’ compliance.
tgt_plain: In its negligence claim, the Claimant alleges that Defendant Nonindustrial Disability Insurance’s (NDI) which provides partial wage replacement to eligible State employees who have a loss of wages due to a non-work-related disability, potentially negligent on some conduct included. It is failing to ensure an appropriate chain of custody of the sample in question and failing to share with Claimant and the testing facilities all factors that could affect or influence testing. Also it is failing to consider and eliminate all factors that could improperly influence testing, failing to prevent "false positives" and/or reporting of test results and failing to have pre-test discussions with Claimant to rule out irregularities that could and/or did affect testing. Lastly the NDI is failing to maintain and/or ensure the maintenance of appropriate quality control testing and/or reporting mechanisms and/or protocols; failing to comply with applicable procedures, regulations, protocols and/or laws regarding reporting and/or testing; and failing to monitor and/or control the compliance of others.

src_legal: In order to survive a motion to dismiss pursuant to Rule 12(b)(6) of the Federal Rules of Civil Procedure, a plaintiff must plead sufficient factual allegations “to state a claim to relief that is plausible on its face.” Twombly, 550 U.S. at 570, 127 S.Ct.
tgt_plain: To avoid being dismissed under Rule 12(b)(6) of the Federal Rules of Civil Procedure, a plaintiff must present enough factual information in their claim to make it "plausible on its face." Twombly, 550 U.S. at 570, 127 S.Ct.

src_legal: The date of admission to a non-VA hospital where a veteran was maintained at VA expense will be accepted as the date of receipt of a claim, if VA maintenance was previously authorized; but if VA maintenance was authorized subsequent to admission, the date VA received notice of admission will be accepted.
tgt_plain: The date of admission of a veteran maintained at VA expense at a non-VA hospital is the date of receipt of a claim if VA maintenance was previously authorized. However, if VA maintenance was granted after the admission, the date VA received is the date of admission.

src_legal: In order to establish a prima facie case for discrimination under § 1981, the plaintiff must show that (1) it is a member of a protected class; (2) it sought to enter into a contractual relationship with the defendant; (3) it met the defendant’s ordinary requirements to enter into a contract with it; (4) it was denied the opportunity to enter into a contract with the defendant that was otherwise afforded to companies owned by whites.
tgt_plain: The suer must show four things to establish a prima facie case of discrimination under § 1981: (1) it is a member of a protected group; (2) it sought to enter into a contractual relationship with the defendant; (3) it satisfied the defendant's normal requirements to enter into a contract with it; and (4) it was denied the opportunity to enter into a contract with the defendant that was typically granted to businesses owned by white people.

src_legal: Courts may issue a writ of mandamus only if three conditions are satisfied: 1) the petitioner must demonstrate that he lacks adequate alternative means to attain the desired relief, thus ensuring that the writ is not used as a substitute for the appeals process, 2) the petitioner must demonstrate a clear and indisputable right to the writ, and 3) the court must be convinced, given the circumstances, that the issuance of a writ is warranted.
tgt_plain: Courts may order an official to complete their duties only if the following three conditions are met: 1) the petitioner must show that he lacks a decent alternative way to gain the desired relief, guaranteeing that the order is not used as a substitute for the appeals process, 2) the petitioner must show a clear and undeniable right to the order, and 3) the court must be convinced, given the situation, that the order is required.

src_legal: In determining when an action is commenced by the Secretary of Labor under this subsection for the purposes of the statutes of limitations provided in section 255(a) of this title, it shall be considered to be commenced in the case of any individual claimant on the date when the complaint is filed if he is specifically named as a party plaintiff in the complaint, or if his name did not so appear, on the subsequent date on which his name is added as a party plaintiff in such action.
tgt_plain: To determine when the Secretary of Labor starts an action under this subsection for the purposes of the statutes of limitations outlined in section 255(a) of this title, it will be considered to have started in the case of any individual claimant on the date the complaint is filed if he is specifically named as a party plaintiff in the complaint, or if his name did not so appear, on the subsequent date on which his name is added as a party plaintiff in such action.

src_legal: While a federal court may exercise supplemental jurisdiction over state law claims “that are so related to claims in the action within [the Court’s] original jurisdiction that they form a part of the same case or controversy under Article III of the United States Constitution,” a court may decline to exercise such jurisdiction where it “has dismissed all claims over which it has original jurisdiction.” Indeed, unless “consideration of judicial economy, convenience and fairness to litigants” weigh in favor of the exercise of supplemental jurisdiction, “a federal court should hesitate to exercise jurisdiction over state claims.” Because Plaintiffs complaint fails to state a viable federal claim, and because this case is at the beginning stages of litigation, the Court declines to exercise supplemental jurisdiction over Plaintiffs state law claims at this time.
tgt_plain: A federal court may give extra decisions over state law if the state law claims are closely related to the main claims in the case. However, if the court dismisses all the primary claims, it can choose not to handle the state law claims. If it's not more efficient, convenient, and fair for everyone involved, the court should be cautious about handling state law claims. Because the Plaintiffs' complaint doesn't have a valid federal claim, and because this case is in the early stages of the legal process, the Court declines to give extra decisions over the Plaintiffs' state law claims right now.

src_legal: While there is no evidence in the Thurman opinion that the plaintiff expressly challengfed the application of the limitations provision on the basis of the change in corporate entity, this Court finds the Sixth Circuit’s application of the Chrysler Corporation provision instructive; in the absence of evidence or legal authority to the contrary, the agreement with Pinnacle precludes a finding of a legitimate expectation of just cause employment.
tgt_plain: The Thurman opinion doesn't have any evidence that the plaintiff challenged the use of the limit provision because of the change in the company's structure. However, this Court considers the Sixth Circuit's application of the Chrysler Corporation provision as helpful. Unless there is evidence or legal support against it, the agreement with Pinnacle prevents a valid claim of expecting fair employment conditions.

src_legal: The Wisconsin Supreme Court concluded that chapter 980 did not require dismissal of Gilbert’s commitment petition because the chapter does not contain language allowing for dismissal in his circumstances, does not set a time period for execution of a commitment order, and provides that an individual may be simultaneously committed under chapter 980 and incarcerated at a DOC facility.
tgt_plain: The Wisconsin Supreme Court finalized that chapter 980 did not require dismissal of Gilbert’s commitment petition because the chapter does not contain language permitting for dismissal in his circumstances, does not arrange a time period for execution of a commitment order, and provides that an individual may be simultaneously committed under chapter 980 and incarcerated at a DOC facility.

src_legal: The court’s central purpose in granting leave to implead a third party is “to promote judicial efficiency by eliminating the necessity for the defendant to bring a separate action against a third individual who may be secondarily or derivatively liable to the defendant for all or part of the plaintiffs original claim.” Sw. Adm’rs, Inc. v. Rozay’s Transfer, 791 F.2d 769, 777 (9th Cir.1986).
tgt_plain: The court's main purpose to granting a third party joining into the lawsuit is to promote judicial efficiency. This is achieved by eliminating the necessity for the defendant to bring a separate action against a third individual who may be indirectly liable to the defendant for all or part of the claimant's original claim.

src_legal: Where, as here, a prisoner “challenges the very fact or duration of his physical imprisonment, and the relief he seeks is a determination that he is entitled to immediate release or a speedier release from that imprisonment, his sole federal remedy is a writ of habeas corpus.” Preiser v. src_legal: Unclean hands “is a self-imposed ordinance that closes the doors of a court of equity to one tainted with inequitableness or bad faith relative to the matter in which he seeks relief’ and originates from “the equitable maxim that ‘he who comes into equity must come with clean hands.’ ” Precision Instrument Mfg.
tgt_plain: “Unclean hands” is a self-imposed rule that if the person asking for help does injustice or acts in bad faith about the issue for which he or she seeks help, this behavior closes the doors of the court of justice. It derives from the motto about the principle of equality, “he who enters righteousness must come with clean hands.” Precision Instrument Mfg.

src_legal: It is clear, therefore, that upon receipt of a letter disputing the factual accuracy of information in a consumer’s file, Section 1681i imposes a duty on a CRA both to reinvestigate and to either delete the disputed information or disclose the current status of the disputed information to the person disputing the information.
tgt_plain: Upon receipt of a letter disputing the factual accuracy of information in a consumer's documents, Section 1681i imposes a duty on a CRA. src_legal: It is an unfair labor practice for a labor organization to, among other things, “interfere with, restrain, or coerce any employee in the exercise by the employee of any right under” the chapter of the CSRA related to union and labor rights, or “to otherwise fail or refuse to comply with any provision of this chapter.” 5 U.S.C.
tgt_plain: An example of an unfair work practice by a workers’ organization under the union and labor rights section of the CSRA is to “intervene, restrict, or compel any employee to exercise any of his rights”. A worker’s organization’s failure or refusal to comply with another provision of the relevant section also constitutes an unjustifiable work practice.

src_legal: The emphasized clause is referred to as the “residual clause,” and in Johnson 2015 the Supreme Court held that the residual clause “denies fair notice to defendants and invites arbitrary enforcement by judges,” and, therefore, violates the due process clause of the Constitution.
tgt_plain: The clause is referred to as the residual clause. In Johnson 2015, the Supreme Court held that the residual clause causes that the defendants are no longer given sufficient notice of a claim against them. It also leads judges to decide arbitrarily. Thus, the residual clause violates the due process clause of the Constitution.

src_legal: First, the court must “tak[e] note of the elements a plaintiff must plead to state a claim.” Second, the court should identify allegations that, “because they are no more than conclusions, are not entitled to the assumption of truth.” Finally, “where there are well-pleaded factual allegations, a court should assume their veracity and then determine whether they plausibly give rise to an entitlement for relief.”
tgt_plain: First, the court must note the elements that should be pleaded by a plaintiff to state a claim. Second, the court should identify allegations. This is necessary because allegations are no more than conclusions, are not entitled to the assumption of truth. After that, if there are well-pleaded factual allegations, a court should assume they are true. Finally, the court should determine whether these well-pleaded factual allegations reasonably give rise to an entitlement for relief.

src_legal: He alleged three federal claims: (1) that the defendants, acting individually, jointly, and in conspiracy, deprived Beaman of a fair trial by withholding material exculpatory evidence in violation of Brady (individual liability); (2) that the defendants conspired to deprive Beaman of material exculpatory evidence (conspiracy liability); and (3) that the defendants failed to intervene in preventing the violation of his rights (failure to intervene liability).
tgt_plain: He advanced three federal claims. Firstly, he claimed that the defendants violated Brady because they withheld the evidence favorable to Beaman and deprived Beaman of a fair trial. The defendants acted individually, jointly, and in conspiracy in do in so (individual liability). Secondly, he claimed that the defendants made a conspiracy to deprive Beaman of material evidence favorable to him (conspiracy liability). Thirdly, he claimed that the defendants should have intervened in order to prevent the violation of his rights, but they failed to do so (failure to intervene liability). He advanced three federal claims. Firstly, he claimed that the defendants violated Brady because they withheld the evidence favorable to Beaman and deprived Beaman of a fair trial. The defendants acted individually, jointly, and in conspiracy in do in so (individual liability). Secondly, he claimed that the defendants made a conspiracy to deprive Beaman of material evidence favorable to him (conspiracy liability). Thirdly, he claimed that the defendants should have intervened in order to prevent the violation of his rights, but they failed to do so (failure to intervene liability).

src_legal: Darren L. DeFlanders (“DeFlanders”) appeals from the decisions of the United States Court of' Appeals for Veterans Claims (“Veterans Court”) affirming the decisions of the Board of Veterans’ Appeals (“the Board”): (i) finding that De-Flanders had not submitted new and material evidence sufficient to reopen claims for service-connected disability compensation for a left knee disability and spots on the lungs; (ii) denying compensation for spots on the brain; and (iii) denying a disability rating in excess of 10% for non-cardiac chest pain.
tgt_plain: Darren L. DeFlanders (“DeFlanders”) goes to higher court against the decision of the United States Court of' Appeals for Veterans Claims (“Veterans Court”) which approves the decisions of the Board of Veterans’ Appeals (“the Board”). In the decision of the Board, firstly it is stated that De-Flanders had not submitted new and material evidence enough to restart the case for service-connected disability compensation for a left knee disability and spots on the lungs. Secondly, the court did not accept the claim on compensation for sports on the brain. Lastly, the court denied a disability rating in excess rating in excess of 10% for chest pain which is not related to heart.

src_legal: Succinctly stated, the Secretary’s contention that § 4.85(a) requires the effective date for an increased disability claim to be set in accordance with the date a Maryland CNC test is administered not only adds words to the regulation that are not there, but it also conflicts with the plain meaning of section 5110(b)(3), which requires the effective date of an award of increased compensation to be “the earliest date as of which it is ascertainable that an increase in disability had occurred.” 38 U.S.C.
tgt_plain: Shortly, the Secretary argues that Article 4.85(a) requires the effective date for an increased disability claim to be set in accordance with the date a Maryland CNC test is administered adds words to the regulation that are not there. Also, it does not fit with the meaning of the section 5110(b)(3), which requires the effective date of a court decision of increased compensation to be “the earliest date as of which it is ascertainable that an increase in disability had occurred.” 38 U.S.C.

src_legal: Given the holding in Koloms, the question remaining for the Court, then, is whether the underlying suits are like the furnace leak in Koloms, namely, the type of isolated, run-of-the-mill result from day-to-day operations and properly covered, or whether they arise from “traditional environmental pollution.” Though it may be more art than science to determine when the isolated consequences of normal business operations end and “traditional environmental pollution” begins, the instant case falls cleanly within the definition.
tgt_plain: Given the judgement in Koloms, the question remaining for the Court is whether the underlying cases arose out of "traditional environmental pollution", such as the furnace leak in Koloms, which is an isolated, ordinary consequence arising from day-to-day operations and of the kind properly covered. This case falls within the definition, even though it is more art than science to determine when the isolated consequences of normal business operations end and “traditional environmental pollution” begins.

src_legal: Works Co. are: (1) the defendant's good faith effort to comply with the statute: (2) the defendant's degree of culpability; (3) the defendant’s histoiy of previous violations; (4) the nature of the public interest in ensuring compliance with the regulations involved; (5) the nature and circumstances of the violation at issue; (6) the gravity of the violation; (7) the defendant’s ability to pay; (8) the appropriateness of the size of the penalty to the defendant’s business and the effect of a penalty on the defendant’s ability to continue doing business; (9) that the penalty not otherwise be shocking to the conscious of the court; (10) the economic benefit gained by the defendant through the violation; (11) the degree of harm to the public; (12) the value of vindicating the agency authority; (13) whether the party sought to be protected by the statute had been adequately compensated for the harm; and (14) such other matters as justice may require.
tgt_plain: The factors considered by the court in determining penalties for Works Co. are as follows: 1. The defendant's genuine attempt to comply with the statute. 2. The level of culpability exhibited by the defendant. 3. The defendant's past record of violations, if any. 4. The importance of ensuring compliance with the relevant regulations for the public interest. 5. The nature and circumstances surrounding the specific violation in question. 6. The seriousness or gravity of the violation. 7. The financial capacity of the defendant to pay the penalty. 8. The appropriateness of the penalty's size in relation to the defendant's business and its impact on the defendant's ability to continue operations. 9. The penalty should not be disproportionately severe and should not shock the conscience of the court. 10. Any economic benefit gained by the defendant as a result of the violation. 11. The extent of harm caused to the public. 12. The value of upholding the authority of the regulatory agency. 13. Whether the party protected by the statute has received adequate compensation for any harm suffered. 14. Any other factors that the concept of justice may require.

src_legal: In his claim for negligence, Plaintiff alleges that Defendant NDI’s potentially negligent conduct includes: (1) failing to ensure a proper chain of custody of the subject specimen; (2) failing to communicate with Plaintiff and the testing facilities any and all factors which could or did affect the testing; (3) failing to take into account and eliminate any and all factors which may improperly influence the tests; (4) failing to prevent testing results of and/or reporting of a “false-positive”; (5) failing to pre-test interview Plaintiff to rule out abnormalities which could and/or did influence the tests; (5) failing to maintain and/or cause to be maintained appropriate quality-control testing and/or reporting mechanisms and/or protocols; (6) failing to comply with governing procedures, regulations, protocols, and/or laws concerning reporting and/or testing; and (7) failing to monitor and/or control others’ compliance.
tgt_plain: In his claim for negligence, Plaintiff argues that Defendant NDI’s potentially acted carelessly since it 1) did not guarantee a proper chain of custody of the subject specimen; (2) did not communicate with Plaintiff and the test facilities any and all factors which could or did affect the testing; (3) did not consider and eliminate any and all factors which may improperly affect the tests; (4) did not provent testing results of and/or reporting of a “false-positive”; (5) did not pre-test interview Plaintiff to rule out abnormalities which could and/or did affect the tests; (5) did not maintain and/or cause to be maintained appropriate quality-control testing and/or reporting mechanisms and/or protocols; (6) did not act in accordance with procedures, regulations, protocols, and/or laws on reporting and/or testing; and (7) did not watch and/or control others’ compliance.

The biochemist would focus on evaluating competitors using scientific parameters like body fat and other statistics.

src_legal: At the time, the state-sponsored terrorism exception did not provide an independent cause of action, but instead acted “as a ‘pass-through’ to substantive causes of action against private individuals that ... may exist in federal, state or international law.”

src_legal: In order to establish a prima facie case for discrimination under § 1981, the plaintiff must show that (1) it is a member of a protected class; (2) it sought to enter into a contractual relationship with the defendant; (3) it met the defendant’s ordinary requirements to enter into a contract with it; (4) it was denied the opportunity to enter into a contract with the defendant that was otherwise afforded to companies owned by whites.
tgt_plain: In order to establish a self-evident case for discrimination under § 1981, the complainant must show that (1) it is a member of a protected class; (2) it sought to enter into a contractual relationship with the accused; (3) it met the accused’s ordinary requirements to enter into a contract with it; (4) it was denied the opportunity to enter into a contract with the accused that was otherwise afforded to companies owned by whites.

src_legal: Courts may issue a writ of mandamus only if three conditions are satisfied: 1) the petitioner must demonstrate that he lacks adequate alternative means to attain the desired relief, thus ensuring that the writ is not used as a substitute for the appeals process, 2) the petitioner must demonstrate a clear and indisputable right to the writ, and 3) the court must be convinced, given the circumstances, that the issuance of a writ is warranted.
tgt_plain: Courts may issue a writ of law only if three conditions are satisfied: 1) the candidate must demonstrate that he lacks adequate alternative means to attain the desired relief, thus ensuring that the writ is not used as a substitute for the appeals process, 2) the candidate must demonstrate a clear and indisputable right to the writ, and 3) the court must be convinced, given the circumstances, that the issuance of a writ is warranted.

src_legal: In determining when an action is commenced by the Secretary of Labor under this subsection for the purposes of the statutes of limitations provided in section 255(a) of this title, it shall be considered to be commenced in the case of any individual claimant on the date when the complaint is filed if he is specifically named as a party plaintiff in the complaint, or if his name did not so appear, on the subsequent date on which his name is added as a party plaintiff in such action.
tgt_plain: In determining when an action is commenced by the Secretary of Labor under this subsection for the purposes of the statutes of limitations provided in section 255(a) of this title, it shall be considered to be commenced in the case of any individual applicant on the date when the complaint is filed if he is specifically named as a party candidate in the complaint, or if his name did not so appear, on the subsequent date on which his name is added as a party candidate in such action.

src_legal: While a federal court may exercise supplemental jurisdiction over state law claims “that are so related to claims in the action within [the Court’s] original jurisdiction that they form a part of the same case or controversy under Article III of the United States Constitution,” a court may decline to exercise such jurisdiction where it “has dismissed all claims over which it has original jurisdiction.” Indeed, unless “consideration of judicial economy, convenience and fairness to litigants” weigh in favor of the exercise of supplemental jurisdiction, “a federal court should hesitate to exercise jurisdiction over state claims.” Because Plaintiffs complaint fails to state a viable federal claim, and because this case is at the beginning stages of litigation, the Court declines to exercise supplemental jurisdiction over Plaintiffs state law claims at this time.
tgt_plain: While a federal court may exercise authority to hear additional claims over state law claims “that are so related to claims in the action within [the Court’s] original jurisdiction that they form a part of the same case or controversy under Article III of the United States Constitution,” a court may decline to hear the claim where it “has rejected all claims over which it has original jurisdiction.” Indeed, unless “consideration of judicial economy, convenience and fairness to parties” weigh in favor of the exercise of the Court exercising authority to hear additional claims, “a federal court should hesitate to exercise jurisdiction over state claims.” Because Claimants argument fails to state an applicable federal claim, and because this case is at the beginning stages of the case, the Court declines to exercise authority to hear additional claims over Claimants state law claims at this time.

src_legal: The court’s central purpose in granting leave to implead a third party is “to promote judicial efficiency by eliminating the necessity for the defendant to bring a separate action against a third individual who may be secondarily or derivatively liable to the defendant for all or part of the plaintiffs original claim.” Sw. Adm’rs, Inc. v. Rozay’s Transfer, 791 F.2d 769, 777 (9th Cir.1986).
tgt_plain: The primary reason for a court granting permission to involve a third party in a lawsuit is to enhance the efficiency of the judicial process. This is achieved by eliminating the need for the defendant to file a separate lawsuit against a third individual who might share some responsibility or liability for the plaintiff's original claim.

src_legal: A reciprocal insurance exchange, “in its pure form ... is a web of contractual relationships between subscribers who agree to insure one another, consummated through a common agent with power of attorney.” The overriding question is whether USAA is properly treated as a corporation or an unincorporated association for purposes of diversity jurisdiction.
tgt_plain: The central question is whether USAA should be considered a corporation or an unincorporated association for diversity jurisdiction purposes, as a reciprocal insurance exchange is essentially a network of contractual relationships between subscribers who agree to provide insurance to each other, facilitated by a common agent with power of attorney.

src_legal: Congress enacted the FDCPA in 1977 “to eliminate abusive debt collection practices by debt collectors, to insure that those debt collectors who refrain from using abusive debt collection practices are not competitively disadvantaged, and to promote consistent State action to protect consumers against debt collection abuses.” 15 U.S.C.
tgt_plain: The purpose of the FDCPA, enacted by Congress in 1977, was to put an end to unfair and abusive practices by debt collectors. It aimed to ensure that debt collectors who refrain from such practices are not at a competitive disadvantage, and to encourage consistent state actions in safeguarding consumers against debt collection abuses.

src_legal: When a federal court sits in diversity, it “has personal jurisdiction over a non-resident defendant if (1) an applicable state long-arm statute confers jurisdiction and (2) the assertion of that jurisdiction is consistent with constitutional due process.” Nichols v. G.D. Searle & Co., 991 F.2d 1195, 1199 (4th Cir.1993).
tgt_plain: In diversity cases, a federal court can exercise personal jurisdiction over a non-resident defendant if two conditions are met. First, the court must have jurisdiction under the state's long-arm statute. Second, the exercise of jurisdiction must comply with constitutional due process. This principle was established in the case Nichols v. G.D. Searle & Co., 991 F.2d 1195, 1199 (4th Cir. 1993).

src_legal: A decision is considered “final and ... appealable where it 1) resolves and seriously affects substantive rights and 2) finally determines the discrete issue to which it is addressed.” Dye v. Brown (In re AFI Holding, Inc.), 530 F.3d 832, 836 (9th Cir.2008) (quoting Schulman v. California (In re Lazar), 237 F.3d 967, 985 (9th Cir.2001)).
tgt_plain: A decision is deemed "final and appealable" when it meets two criteria. First, it must substantially impact and affect substantive rights. Second, it must conclusively determine the specific issue it addresses. This principle was articulated in Dye v. Brown (In re AFI Holding, Inc.), 530 F.3d 832, 836 (9th Cir. 2008), citing Schulman v. California (In re Lazar), 237 F.3d 967, 985 (9th Cir. 2001).

src_legal: Once admitted into the Minnesota Department of Corrections (“MDOC”) system, Brooks received a chemical-dependency assessment, as all new inmates are required to have under Minnesota law, and was ordered to complete treatment in order to be transferred to a lower-security prison, qualify for work release, and avoid disciplinary sanctions.
tgt_plain: Upon entering the Minnesota Department of Corrections ("MDOC") system, Brooks underwent a chemical-dependency assessment, as mandated by Minnesota law for all new inmates. It was determined that Brooks must complete treatment in order to be transferred to a lower-security prison, become eligible for work release, and prevent disciplinary penalties.

src_legal: Such a need is established if either: (1) failure to obtain expedited processing would pose an “imminent threat to the life or physical safety of an individual”; or (2) the requester is “primarily engaged in disseminating information” and shows an “urgency to inform the public concerning actual or alleged Federal Government ■ activity.” 5 U.S.C.
tgt_plain: There are two conditions under which the need for expedited processing is justified. Firstly, if not obtaining expedited processing would create an immediate threat to the life or physical safety of an individual. Secondly, if the requester is primarily involved in disseminating information and can demonstrate an urgency to inform the public about actual or alleged activities of the Federal Government. This is governed by 5 U.S.C. (United States Code).

src_legal: Where, as here, a prisoner “challenges the very fact or duration of his physical imprisonment, and the relief he seeks is a determination that he is entitled to immediate release or a speedier release from that imprisonment, his sole federal remedy is a writ of habeas corpus.” Preiser v. Rodriguez, 411 U.S. 475, 500, 93 S.Ct.
tgt_plain: Where, as here, a prisoner “challenges the very fact or duration of his physical imprisonment, and the release he seeks is a determination that he is entitled to immediate release or a speedier release from that imprisonment, his sole federal remedy is a ordinance used to bring a prisoner or other detainee before the court to determine if the person's imprisonment or detention is lawful.” Preiser v. Rodriguez, 411 U.S. 475, 500, 93 S.Ct.

src_legal: This court has jurisdiction to review a decision of the CAVC “with respect to the validity of a decision of the Court on a rule of law or of any statute or regulation ... or any interpretation thereof (other than a determination as to a factual matter) that was relied on by the [CAVC] in making the decision.” 38 U.S.C.
tgt_plain: This court has the competence to review a decision of the United States Court of Appeals for Veterans Claims ("CAVC") in terms of the validity of CAVC's decision as regards to application of rule of law, or any written law, or regulation, or any of their interpretation that were relied on by the CAVC in decision making. However, this court does not have the competence to review a decision of CAVC in terms of the determination of the facts of the case. Title 38 U.S. Code

src_legal: It is clear, therefore, that upon receipt of a letter disputing the factual accuracy of information in a consumer’s file, Section 1681i imposes a duty on a CRA both to reinvestigate and to either delete the disputed information or disclose the current status of the disputed information to the person disputing the information.
tgt_plain: Therefore, it is clear that, under Section 1681i, if a consumer disputes the factual accuracy of the information in her/his consumer file, CRA is under a duty both to reinvestigate and to either delete the disputed information or disclose the current status of the disputed information to the consumer as the CRA receives the consumer's letter disputing the factual accuracy of the information in her/his file.

src_legal: Where, as here, a prisoner “challeng[es] the very fact or duration of his physical imprisonment, and the relief he seeks is a determination that he is entitled to immediate release or a speedier release from that imprisonment, his sole federal remedy is a writ of habeas corpus.” Preiser v. Rodriguez, 411 U.S. 475, 500, 93 S.Ct.
tgt_plain: If a prisoner "questions a reason or duration of his physical imprisonment" like here, and he wants "the court to determine that he should be released immediately or released from that imprisonment faster, his only legal solution provided under federal law is requesting to be called to the court." Preiser v. Rodriguez, 411 U.S. 475, 500, 93 S.Ct.

src_legal: It is an unfair labor practice for a labor organization to, among other things, “interfere with, restrain, or coerce any employee in the exercise by the employee of any right under” the chapter of the CSRA related to union and labor rights, or “to otherwise fail or refuse to comply with any provision of this chapter.” 5 U.S.C.
tgt_plain: Among other things, “interfering with, limiting, or forcing any employee in the exercise of any of his/her rights under” the chapter of the Civil Service Reform Act related to labor unions and labor rights are unfair labor practices for a labor organization. src_legal: The emphasized clause is referred to as the “residual clause,” and in Johnson 2015 the Supreme Court held that the residual clause “denies fair notice to defendants and invites arbitrary enforcement by judges,” and, therefore, violates the due process clause of the Constitution.
tgt_plain: The emphasized clause is referred to as the "residual clause." The Supreme Court (in Johnson 2015) held that the residual clause does not allow fair notice to the defendants and results in arbitrary enforcement by judges. Accordingly, this clause violates the due process clause of the Constitution.

tgt_plain: First, the court must “tak[e] note of the elements a claimant must request to tell a claim.” Second, the court should find claims that, “because they are no more than conclusions, are not authorized to the assumption of truth.” Finally, “where there are well-defended factual claims, a court should accept their truth and then decide whether they possibly give rise to a right to relief.”

src_legal: He alleged three federal claims: (1) that the defendants, acting individually, jointly, and in conspiracy, deprived Beaman of a fair trial by withholding material exculpatory evidence in violation of Brady (individual liability); (2) that the defendants conspired to deprive Beaman of material exculpatory evidence (conspiracy liability); and (3) that the defendants failed to intervene in preventing the violation of his rights (failure to intervene liability).

src_legal: Darren L. DeFlanders (“DeFlanders”) appeals from the decisions of the United States Court of' Appeals for Veterans Claims (“Veterans Court”) affirming the decisions of the Board of Veterans’ Appeals (“the Board”): (i) finding that De-Flanders had not submitted new and material evidence sufficient to reopen claims for service-connected disability compensation for a left knee disability and spots on the lungs; (ii) denying compensation for spots on the brain; and (iii) denying a disability rating in excess of 10% for non-cardiac chest pain.
tgt_plain: Darren L. DeFlanders (“DeFlanders”) applies from the decisions of the United States Court of' Appeals for Veterans Claims (“Veterans Court”) which approved the decisions of the Board of Veterans’ Appeals (“the Board”). It found that De-Flanders had not provided new and material evidence sufficient to reopen claims for service-connected disability compensation for a left knee disability and spots on the lungs; it rejected compensation for spots on the brain; and a disability rating in excess of 10% for non-cardiac chest pain.

src_legal: Succinctly stated, the Secretary’s contention that § 4.85(a) requires the effective date for an increased disability claim to be set in accordance with the date a Maryland CNC test is administered not only adds words to the regulation that are not there, but it also conflicts with the plain meaning of section 5110(b)(3), which requires the effective date of an award of increased compensation to be “the earliest date as of which it is ascertainable that an increase in disability had occurred.” 38 U.S.C.
tgt_plain: Briefly, the Secretary argues that § 4.85(a) requires the effective date for an increased disability claim to be set in accordance with the date a Maryland CNC test is administered adds words to the regulation that are not clearly included. The Secretary also argues that it also conflicts with the simple meaning of section 5110(b)(3), which requires the effective date of an award of increased compensation to be “the earliest date as of which it is ascertainable that an increase in disability had occurred.” 38 U.S.C.

src_legal: Given the holding in Koloms, the question remaining for the Court, then, is whether the underlying suits are like the furnace leak in Koloms, namely, the type of isolated, run-of-the-mill result from day-to-day operations and properly covered, or whether they arise from “traditional environmental pollution.” Though it may be more art than science to determine when the isolated consequences of normal business operations end and “traditional environmental pollution” begins, the instant case falls cleanly within the definition.
tgt_plain: Given the decision in Koloms, the unanswered question for the Court is hether the underlying suits are like the furnace leak in Koloms, namely, the type of isolated, run-of-the-mill result from day-to-day operations and properly covered, or whether they arise from “traditional environmental pollution.” Though it may be more art than science to determine when the isolated consequences of normal business operations end and “traditional environmental pollution” begins, the instant case is covered within the definition.

src_legal: Works Co. are: (1) the defendant's good faith effort to comply with the statute: (2) the defendant's degree of culpability; (3) the defendant’s histoiy of previous violations; (4) the nature of the public interest in ensuring compliance with the regulations involved; (5) the nature and circumstances of the violation at issue; (6) the gravity of the violation; (7) the defendant’s ability to pay; (8) the appropriateness of the size of the penalty to the defendant’s business and the effect of a penalty on the defendant’s ability to continue doing business; (9) that the penalty not otherwise be shocking to the conscious of the court; (10) the economic benefit gained by the defendant through the violation; (11) the degree of harm to the public; (12) the value of vindicating the agency authority; (13) whether the party sought to be protected by the statute had been adequately compensated for the harm; and (14) such other matters as justice may require.
tgt_plain: Works Co. are: (1) the defendant's good faith effort to act in accordance with the statute: (2) the defendant's degree of culpability; (3) the defendant’s previous violations; (4) the nature of the public interest to ensure compliance with the regulations involved; (5) the nature and circumstances of the violation at issue; (6) the gravity of the violation; (7) the defendant’s ability to pay; (8) the appropriateness of the size of the penalty to the defendant’s business and the effect of a penalty on the defendant’s ability to continue doing business; (9) that the penalty not otherwise be shocking to the conscious of the court; (10) the economic benefit gained by the defendant through the violation; (11) the degree of harm to the public; (12) the value of vindicating the agency authority; (13) whether the party sought to be protected by the statute had been adequately compensated for the harm; and (14) such other matters as justice may require.

src_legal: In his claim for negligence, Plaintiff alleges that Defendant NDI’s potentially negligent conduct includes: (1) failing to ensure a proper chain of custody of the subject specimen; (2) failing to communicate with Plaintiff and the testing facilities any and all factors which could or did affect the testing; (3) failing to take into account and eliminate any and all factors which may improperly influence the tests; (4) failing to prevent testing results of and/or reporting of a “false-positive”; (5) failing to pre-test interview Plaintiff to rule out abnormalities which could and/or did influence the tests; (5) failing to maintain and/or cause to be maintained appropriate quality-control testing and/or reporting mechanisms and/or protocols; (6) failing to comply with governing procedures, regulations, protocols, and/or laws concerning reporting and/or testing; and (7) failing to monitor and/or control others’ compliance.
tgt_plain: In his claim for negligence, Claimant alleges that Respondent NDI’s potentially negligent conduct includes: (1) failing to ensure a proper documentation of transfer of the subject material; (2) failing to communicate with Claimant and the testing facilities any and all factors which could or did affect the testing; (3) failing to take into account and eliminate any and all factors which may improperly influence the tests; (4) failing to prevent testing results of and/or reporting of a “false-positive”; (5) failing to pre-test interview Claimant to rule out abnormalities which could and/or did influence the tests; (5) failing to maintain and/or cause to be maintained appropriate quality-control testing and/or reporting mechanisms and/or protocols; (6) failing to comply with governing procedures, regulations, protocols, and/or laws concerning reporting and/or testing; and (7) failing to monitor and/or control others’ compliance.

src_legal: As a result of this holding, we need not address whether section 5121 of title 38 could be inapplicable to FVECF claims for the additional reason that section 5121 may be preempted by ARRA section 1002(c), which governs the scope of FVECF survivor claims.

src_legal: The date of admission to a non-VA hospital where a veteran was maintained at VA expense will be accepted as the date of receipt of a claim, if VA maintenance was previously authorized; but if VA maintenance was authorized subsequent to admission, the date VA received notice of admission will be accepted.
tgt_plain: The date of admission to a non-VA hospital where a veteran was maintained at VA expense will be accepted as the date of receipt of a claim, if VA maintenance was previously authorized; but if VA maintenance was authorized subsequent to admission, the date VA received notice of admission will be accepted.

src_legal: In order to establish a prima facie case for discrimination under § 1981, the plaintiff must show that (1) it is a member of a protected class; (2) it sought to enter into a contractual relationship with the defendant; (3) it met the defendant’s ordinary requirements to enter into a contract with it; (4) it was denied the opportunity to enter into a contract with the defendant that was otherwise afforded to companies owned by whites.
tgt_plain: In order to establish a arguable claim for discrimination under § 1981, the claimant must show that (1) it is a member of a protected class; (2) it try to make  a contract with the accused; (3) it met the defendant’s ordinary requirements to enter into a contract with it; (4) it was denied the opportunity to enter into a contract with the accused that was otherwise provided to companies owned by whites.

src_legal: Courts may issue a writ of mandamus only if three conditions are satisfied: 1) the petitioner must demonstrate that he lacks adequate alternative means to attain the desired relief, thus ensuring that the writ is not used as a substitute for the appeals process, 2) the petitioner must demonstrate a clear and indisputable right to the writ, and 3) the court must be convinced, given the circumstances, that the issuance of a writ is warranted.
tgt_plain: Courts may issue an order only if three conditions are satisfied: 1) the requester must demonstrate that he lacks adequate alternative means to attain the desired relief, thus ensuring that the writ is not used as a substitute for the appeals process, 2) the requester must demonstrate a clear and indisputable right to the court order, and 3) the court must be convinced, given the circumstances, that the giving a order from a court is necessary.

src_legal: In determining when an action is commenced by the Secretary of Labor under this subsection for the purposes of the statutes of limitations provided in section 255(a) of this title, it shall be considered to be commenced in the case of any individual claimant on the date when the complaint is filed if he is specifically named as a party plaintiff in the complaint, or if his name did not so appear, on the subsequent date on which his name is added as a party plaintiff in such action.
tgt_plain: In determining when an action is started by the Secretary of Labor under this subsection for the purposes of the limitation period provided in section 255(a) of this title, it shall be considered to be started in the case of any individual claimant on the date when the complaint is filed if he is specifically named as a party plaintiff in the complaint, or if his name did not so appear, on the subsequent date on which his name is added as a party plaintiff in such action.

src_legal: While a federal court may exercise supplemental jurisdiction over state law claims “that are so related to claims in the action within [the Court’s] original jurisdiction that they form a part of the same case or controversy under Article III of the United States Constitution,” a court may decline to exercise such jurisdiction where it “has dismissed all claims over which it has original jurisdiction.” Indeed, unless “consideration of judicial economy, convenience and fairness to litigants” weigh in favor of the exercise of supplemental jurisdiction, “a federal court should hesitate to exercise jurisdiction over state claims.” Because Plaintiffs complaint fails to state a viable federal claim, and because this case is at the beginning stages of litigation, the Court declines to exercise supplemental jurisdiction over Plaintiffs state law claims at this time.
tgt_plain: While a federal court may exercise additional jurisdiction over state law claims “that are so related to claims in the action within [the Court’s] original jurisdiction that they form a part of the same case or controversy under Article III of the United States Constitution,” a court may reject to exercise such jurisdiction where it “has dismissed all claims over which it has original jurisdiction.” Indeed, unless “consideration of judicial economy, convenience and fairness to litigants” weigh in favor of the exercise of supplemental jurisdiction, “a federal court should hesitate to exercise jurisdiction over state claims.” Because Plaintiffs complaint fails to state a viable federal claim, and because this case is at the beginning stages of litigation, the Court rejects to exercise additional jurisdiction over Plaintiffs state law claims at this time.

src_legal: The Wisconsin Supreme Court concluded that chapter 980 did not require dismissal of Gilbert’s commitment petition because the chapter does not contain language allowing for dismissal in his circumstances, does not set a time period for execution of a commitment order, and provides that an individual may be simultaneously committed under chapter 980 and incarcerated at a DOC facility.
tgt_plain: The Wisconsin Supreme Court concluded that chapter 980 did not require termination of Gilbert’s commitment petition because the chapter does not contain language allowing for it in his circumstances, does not set a time period for execution of a custody order, and provides that an individual may be simultaneously committed under chapter 980 and incarcerated at a DOC facility.

src_legal: The court’s central purpose in granting leave to implead a third party is “to promote judicial efficiency by eliminating the necessity for the defendant to bring a separate action against a third individual who may be secondarily or derivatively liable to the defendant for all or part of the plaintiffs original claim.” Sw. Adm’rs, Inc. v. Rozay’s Transfer, 791 F.2d 769, 777 (9th Cir.1986).
tgt_plain: The court’s central purpose in allowing to sue a third party is to promote judicial efficiency by eliminating the necessity for the defendant to bring a separate action against a third person. This third person may be connectedly responsible to the defendant for all or part of the plaintiffs original request.” Sw. Adm’rs, Inc. v. Rozay’s Transfer, 791 F.2d 769, 777 (9th Cir.1986).

src_legal: Congress enacted the FDCPA in 1977 “to eliminate abusive debt collection practices by debt collectors, to insure that those debt collectors who refrain from using abusive debt collection practices are not competitively disadvantaged, and to promote consistent State action to protect consumers against debt collection abuses.” 15 U.S.C.

Second, to ensure that those debt collectors who avoid abusive debt collection practices are not competitively disadvantaged. Third, to promote consistent State action to protect consumers against debt collection abuses.” 15 U.S.C.

src_legal: When a federal court sits in diversity, it “has personal jurisdiction over a non-resident defendant if (1) an applicable state long-arm statute confers jurisdiction and (2) the assertion of that jurisdiction is consistent with constitutional due process.” Nichols v. G.D. Searle & Co., 991 F.2d 1195, 1199 (4th Cir.1993).
tgt_plain: If an applicable state far reaching statute confers jurisdiction and the assertion of that jurisdiction is consistent with constitutional due process, a federal court has personal jurisdiction over a non-resident defendant. ” Nichols v. G.D. Searle & Co., 991 F.2d 1195, 1199 (4th Cir.1993).

src_legal: A decision is considered “final and ... appealable where it 1) resolves and seriously affects substantive rights and 2) finally determines the discrete issue to which it is addressed.” Dye v. Brown (In re AFI Holding, Inc.), 530 F.3d 832, 836 (9th Cir.2008) (quoting Schulman v. California (In re Lazar), 237 F.3d 967, 985 (9th Cir.2001)).
tgt_plain: If a decision resolves and seriously affects essential rights and finally determines the concrete issue to which it is addressed, that decision is considered "final and appealable". Dye v. Brown (In re AFI Holding, Inc.), 530 F.3d 832, 836 (9th Cir.2008) (quoting Schulman v. California (In re Lazar), 237 F.3d 967, 985 (9th Cir.2001)).

tgt_plain: Once admitted into the Minnesota Department of Corrections (“MDOC”) system, Brooks received a chemical-dependency assessment, as all new prisoners are required to have under Minnesota law. He was ordered to complete treatment in order to be transferred to a lower-security prison, qualify for work release, and avoid disciplinary sanctions.

src_legal: Where a party fails to perform its obligations as required, any assignment of this Agreement without the prior written consent of the other party shall be null and void, without prejudice to any other remedy available at law or in equity.

src_legal: The obligations set forth in this section shall survive termination of this Agreement, and the parties acknowledge that time is of the essence with respect to the performance of their respective obligations.

src_legal: In spite of any other clause of this Agreement, the landlord may enter the premises upon reasonable prior notice to inspect, repair, or show the property to prospective tenants or purchasers, unless the parties expressly agree otherwise in a signed writing.
tgt_plain: The landlord may enter the property with reasonable notice to inspect, make repairs, or show it to potential tenants or buyers.

src_legal: Despite any other provision of this Agreement, the employee agrees not to compete with the employer's business within a fifty mile radius for one year after the end of employment, unless the parties expressly agree otherwise in a signed writing.
tgt_plain: The employee agrees not to work for a competing business within fifty miles for one year after leaving.

src_legal: Notwithstanding any other provision of this Agreement, the borrower shall provide the lender with quarterly financial statements prepared in accordance with generally accepted accounting principles, unless the parties expressly agree otherwise in a signed writing.
tgt_plain: The borrower must send the lender quarterly financial statements that follow standard accounting rules.

src_legal: The parties agree that electronic signatures shall have the same legal effect as original handwritten signatures, unless the parties expressly agree otherwise in a signed writing.
tgt_plain: The parties agree that electronic signatures are legally equal to handwritten ones.

src_legal: Despite any other provision of this Agreement, the service provider shall maintain industry-standard security measures to protect customer data stored on its systems, unless the parties expressly agree otherwise in a signed writing.
tgt_plain: The service provider must use typical industry security practices to protect customer data it stores.

src_legal: Notwithstanding any other provision of this Agreement, the parties consent to the exclusive jurisdiction of the federal and state courts located in the County of Cook, Illinois, unless the parties expressly agree otherwise in a signed writing.
tgt_plain: Both sides agree that only the courts in Cook County, Illinois will hear disputes about the contract.

src_legal: The buyer shall have the right to inspect the goods upon delivery and may reject any goods that do not conform to the specifications, unless the parties expressly agree otherwise in a signed writing.
tgt_plain: The buyer may inspect the goods on delivery and refuse items that do not meet the agreed specifications.

src_legal: The consultant shall perform the services in a professional and workmanlike manner consistent with generally accepted industry standards, unless the parties expressly agree otherwise in a signed writing.
tgt_plain: The consultant must do the work professionally and in line with common industry standards.

src_legal: Notwithstanding any other provision of this Agreement, the parties agree that any modification of this Agreement must be in writing and signed by authorized representatives of both parties, unless the parties expressly agree otherwise in a signed writing.
tgt_plain: Any change to the contract must be written and signed by authorized people from both sides.

src_legal: Regardless of any conflicting provision in this Agreement, the franchisee shall operate the franchised business strictly in accordance with the franchisor's manuals, policies, and specifications, unless the parties expressly agree otherwise in a signed writing.
tgt_plain: The franchise owner must run the business according to the franchisor's manuals and rules.

src_legal: Regardless of any conflicting provision in this Agreement, the obligor shall indemnify and hold harmless the indemnitee from and against all claims arising from the obligor's negligence or willful misconduct, unless the parties expressly agree otherwise in a signed writing.
tgt_plain: The party at fault must reimburse the other party for claims caused by its negligence or intentional wrongdoing.

src_legal: In spite of any other clause of this Agreement, the parties acknowledge that no partnership, joint venture, or agency relationship is created by this Agreement, unless the parties expressly agree otherwise in a signed writing.
tgt_plain: The parties agree that this contract does not make them partners, joint venturers, or agents of each other.

src_legal: Notwithstanding any other provision of this Agreement, the tenant shall return the premises to the landlord in substantially the same condition as received, ordinary wear and tear excepted, unless the parties expressly agree otherwise in a signed writing.
tgt_plain: The tenant must give the space back in almost the same condition as at move in, allowing for normal wear and tear.

src_legal: The obligation to maintain confidentiality shall survive termination or expiration of this Agreement for a period of three years, unless the parties expressly agree otherwise in a signed writing.
tgt_plain: The duty to keep information confidential continues for three years after the contract ends.

src_legal: For the avoidance of doubt, the nonbreaching party may seek specific performance or injunctive relief from a court of competent jurisdiction, and no party shall rely on any prior or contemporaneous oral statement to the contrary.
tgt_plain: The party that did not breach the contract may ask a court to force performance or stop wrongful conduct.

src_legal: For the avoidance of doubt, each party shall maintain the confidentiality of all proprietary or trade secret information disclosed under this Agreement, and no party shall rely on any prior or contemporaneous oral statement to the contrary.
tgt_plain: Each side must keep shared confidential business information secret.

src_legal: To avoid any uncertainty, no waiver of any provision shall be effective unless made in writing and signed by the waiving party, and no party shall rely on any prior or contemporaneous oral statement to the contrary.
tgt_plain: A party only gives up a contract right if it does so in a written, signed document.

src_legal: For the avoidance of doubt, the party in default shall be afforded a reasonable opportunity to cure such default within thirty days after receiving written notice, and no party shall rely on any prior or contemporaneous oral statement to the contrary.
tgt_plain: The side that violated the contract gets thirty days after written notice to fix the problem.

src_legal: To avoid any uncertainty, all notices and other communications required or permitted under this Agreement shall be in writing and delivered by certified mail or reputable courier service, and no party shall rely on any prior or contemporaneous oral statement to the contrary.
tgt_plain: All formal notices must be written and sent by certified mail or a well known delivery service.

src_legal: To avoid any uncertainty, the laws of the State of New York shall govern the validity, interpretation, and enforcement of this Agreement, without regard to its conflict of law rules, and no party shall rely on any prior or contemporaneous oral statement to the contrary.
tgt_plain: New York law controls how this contract is interpreted and enforced.

src_legal: Any assignment of this Agreement or of any rights or obligations hereunder without the prior written consent of the other party shall be null and void, and no party shall rely on any prior or contemporaneous oral statement to the contrary.
tgt_plain: A party cannot transfer this contract to someone else without the other side's written consent.

src_legal: For the avoidance of doubt, the parties acknowledge and agree that time is of the essence with respect to the performance of all obligations set forth herein, and no party shall rely on any prior or contemporaneous oral statement to the contrary.
tgt_plain: Both sides agree that meeting the contract deadlines is very important.

src_legal: For the avoidance of doubt, the employee shall comply with all policies, procedures, and codes of conduct adopted by the employer from time to time, and no party shall rely on any prior or contemporaneous oral statement to the contrary.
tgt_plain: The employee must follow the employer's current rules and codes of conduct.

src_legal: For the avoidance of doubt, the customer shall remit full payment of all undisputed amounts within thirty days after receipt of a properly issued invoice, and no party shall rely on any prior or contemporaneous oral statement to the contrary.
tgt_plain: The customer must pay the amount it does not dispute within thirty days of receiving a correct bill.

src_legal: For the avoidance of doubt, interest shall accrue on any overdue amounts at the rate of one and one half percent per month or the maximum rate allowed by law, whichever is lower, and no party shall rely on any prior or contemporaneous oral statement to the contrary.
tgt_plain: Late payments will accrue interest up to the legal limit.

src_legal: For clarity, the contractor shall obtain and maintain at its own expense all licenses, permits, and approvals required to perform the services described herein, and no party shall rely on any prior or contemporaneous oral statement to the contrary.
tgt_plain: The contractor must pay for and keep any licenses and permits needed to do the work.

src_legal: For the avoidance of doubt, the limitation of liability set forth in this section shall not apply to damages arising from a party's gross negligence or willful misconduct, and no party shall rely on any prior or contemporaneous oral statement to the contrary.
tgt_plain: The liability cap does not apply if a party acts with gross negligence or on purpose.

src_legal: The data controller shall implement appropriate technical and organizational measures to protect personal data against unauthorized access, use, or disclosure, and no party shall rely on any prior or contemporaneous oral statement to the contrary.
tgt_plain: The organization handling personal data must use proper safeguards to prevent unauthorized access or misuse.

src_legal: For the sake of certainty, the data subject shall have the right to access, correct, or request deletion of personal data processed by the controller, subject to applicable law, and no party shall rely on any prior or contemporaneous oral statement to the contrary.
tgt_plain: The person whose data is used may see it, correct it, or ask that it be deleted when the law allows.

src_legal: The tenant shall not make any structural alterations or improvements to the leased premises without the prior written consent of the landlord, and no party shall rely on any prior or contemporaneous oral statement to the contrary.
tgt_plain: The tenant needs the landlord's written approval before making structural changes to the space.

src_legal: For clarity, the insurance coverage required hereunder shall name the other party as an additional insured on a primary and noncontributory basis, and no party shall rely on any prior or contemporaneous oral statement to the contrary.
tgt_plain: The required insurance policy must list the other party as an additional insured with primary coverage.

src_legal: For the sake of certainty, the company may terminate this Agreement for convenience upon thirty days' prior written notice to the other party, and no party shall rely on any prior or contemporaneous oral statement to the contrary.
tgt_plain: The company can end the contract for any reason by giving thirty days' written notice.

src_legal: For the avoidance of doubt, each party shall use commercially reasonable efforts to mitigate any damages arising from a breach of this Agreement, and no party shall rely on any prior or contemporaneous oral statement to the contrary.
tgt_plain: Each side must take reasonable steps to reduce the harm caused by a contract breach.

src_legal: To avoid any uncertainty, any controversy or claim arising out of or relating to this Agreement shall be settled by binding arbitration administered by a recognized arbitral provider, and no party shall rely on any prior or contemporaneous oral statement to the contrary.
tgt_plain: Any dispute about this contract will be decided by binding arbitration run by a recognized provider.

src_legal: The shareholder hereby irrevocably appoints the company as his or her proxy to vote the shares in accordance with the terms of this Agreement, and no party shall rely on any prior or contemporaneous oral statement to the contrary.
tgt_plain: The shareholder gives the company lasting authority to vote the shares as the agreement requires.

src_legal: As a prerequisite to exercising any rights under this Agreement, the guarantor hereby unconditionally guarantees the punctual payment and performance of all obligations of the borrower under the loan documents, and the party seeking relief shall provide prompt written notice.
tgt_plain: The guarantor promises to pay and perform all of the borrower's obligations on time if the borrower does not.

src_legal: Before any rights under this Agreement may be exercised, the license granted herein is nonexclusive, nontransferable, and limited to internal business use by the licensee, and the party seeking relief shall provide prompt written notice.
tgt_plain: The license lets the licensee use the product only internally, and it cannot be transferred or shared with others.

src_legal: Prior to the exercise of any rights under this Agreement, the parties shall treat the terms and existence of settlement negotiations as confidential and shall not disclose them to third parties, and the party seeking relief shall provide prompt written notice.
tgt_plain: Both sides must keep settlement talks secret and not share details with outsiders.

src_legal: Prior to the exercise of any rights under this Agreement, the landlord may enter the premises upon reasonable prior notice to inspect, repair, or show the property to prospective tenants or purchasers, and the party seeking relief shall provide prompt written notice.
tgt_plain: The landlord may enter the property with reasonable notice to inspect, make repairs, or show it to potential tenants or buyers.

src_legal: Before any rights under this Agreement may be exercised, the employee agrees not to compete with the employer's business within a fifty mile radius for one year after the end of employment, and the party seeking relief shall provide prompt written notice.
tgt_plain: The employee agrees not to work for a competing business within fifty miles for one year after leaving.

src_legal: Prior to the exercise of any rights under this Agreement, the borrower shall provide the lender with quarterly financial statements prepared in accordance with generally accepted accounting principles, and the party seeking relief shall provide prompt written notice.
tgt_plain: The borrower must send the lender quarterly financial statements that follow standard accounting rules.

src_legal: As a prerequisite to exercising any rights under this Agreement, the parties agree that electronic signatures shall have the same legal effect as original handwritten signatures, and the party seeking relief shall provide prompt written notice.
tgt_plain: The parties agree that electronic signatures are legally equal to handwritten ones.

src_legal: As a prior condition to asserting any rights under this Agreement, the service provider shall maintain industry-standard security measures to protect customer data stored on its systems, and the party seeking relief shall provide prompt written notice.
tgt_plain: The service provider must use typical industry security practices to protect customer data it stores.

src_legal: Before any rights under this Agreement may be exercised, the parties consent to the exclusive jurisdiction of the federal and state courts located in the County of Cook, Illinois, and the party seeking relief shall provide prompt written notice.
tgt_plain: Both sides agree that only the courts in Cook County, Illinois will hear disputes about the contract.

src_legal: As a prior condition to asserting any rights under this Agreement, the buyer shall have the right to inspect the goods upon delivery and may reject any goods that do not conform to the specifications, and the party seeking relief shall provide prompt written notice.
tgt_plain: The buyer may inspect the goods on delivery and refuse items that do not meet the agreed specifications.

src_legal: Before any rights under this Agreement may be exercised, the consultant shall perform the services in a professional and workmanlike manner consistent with generally accepted industry standards, and the party seeking relief shall provide prompt written notice.
tgt_plain: The consultant must do the work professionally and in line with common industry standards.

src_legal: As a prerequisite to exercising any rights under this Agreement, the parties agree that any modification of this Agreement must be in writing and signed by authorized representatives of both parties, and the party seeking relief shall provide prompt written notice.
tgt_plain: Any change to the contract must be written and signed by authorized people from both sides.

src_legal: Before any rights under this Agreement may be exercised, the franchisee shall operate the franchised business strictly in accordance with the franchisor's manuals, policies, and specifications, and the party seeking relief shall provide prompt written notice.
tgt_plain: The franchise owner must run the business according to the franchisor's manuals and rules.

src_legal: As a prior condition to asserting any rights under this Agreement, the obligor shall indemnify and hold harmless the indemnitee from and against all claims arising from the obligor's negligence or willful misconduct, and the party seeking relief shall provide prompt written notice.
tgt_plain: The party at fault must reimburse the other party for claims caused by its negligence or intentional wrongdoing.

src_legal: Before any rights under this Agreement may be exercised, the parties acknowledge that no partnership, joint venture, or agency relationship is created by this Agreement, and the party seeking relief shall provide prompt written notice.
tgt_plain: The parties agree that this contract does not make them partners, joint venturers, or agents of each other.

src_legal: As a prerequisite to exercising any rights under this Agreement, the tenant shall return the premises to the landlord in substantially the same condition as received, ordinary wear and tear excepted, and the party seeking relief shall provide prompt written notice.
tgt_plain: The tenant must give the space back in almost the same condition as at move in, allowing for normal wear and tear.

src_legal: Before any rights under this Agreement may be exercised, the obligation to maintain confidentiality shall survive termination or expiration of this Agreement for a period of three years, and the party seeking relief shall provide prompt written notice.
tgt_plain: The duty to keep information confidential continues for three years after the contract ends.

tgt_plain: Deadlines are very important for all tasks and dates in this deal.
