src_legal: In the 3rd hour, we will delve into our first case, which comes courtesy of Professor Pamela Karlan's course in torts.
tgt_plain: In the 3rd hour, we will explore our first case, which comes from Professor Pamela Karlan's course in torts.

src_legal: We consider whether a law enforcement official can, consistent with the Fourth Amendment, attempt to stop a fleeing motorist from continuing his public-endangering flight by ramming the motorist's car from behind.
tgt_plain: We consider whether a law enforcement official can, consistent with the Fourth Amendment protection against unreasonable searches and seizures, attempt to stop a fleeing driver from continuing his dangerous flight by ramming the driver's car from behind.

src_legal: Put another way: Can an officer take actions that place a fleeing motorist at risk of serious injury or death in order to stop the motorist's flight from endangering the lives of innocent bystanders?
tgt_plain: Put another way: Can an officer take actions that place a fleeing driver at risk of serious injury or death in order to stop the driver's flight from endangering the lives of innocent bystanders?

src_legal: In March 2001, a Georgia county deputy clocked respondent's vehicle traveling at 73 miles per hour on a road with a 55-mile-per-hour speed limit.
tgt_plain: In March 2001, a Georgia county deputy measured the defendant's vehicle traveling at 73 miles per hour on a road with a 55-mile-per-hour speed limit.

src_legal: The deputy activated his blue flashing lights indicating that respondent should pull over.
tgt_plain: The deputy turned on his blue flashing lights indicating that the defendant should pull over.

src_legal: Instead, respondent sped away, initiating a chase down what is in most portions a two-lane road, at speeds exceeding 85 miles per hour.
tgt_plain: Instead, the defendant sped away, starting a chase down what is mostly a two-lane road, at speeds exceeding 85 miles per hour.

src_legal: Petitioner, Deputy Timothy Scott, heard the radio communication and joined the pursuit along with other officers.
tgt_plain: The plaintiff, Deputy Timothy Scott, heard the radio communication and joined the pursuit along with other officers.

src_legal: In the midst of the chase, respondent pulled into the parking lot of a shopping center and was nearly boxed in by the various police vehicles.
tgt_plain: In the middle of the chase, the defendant pulled into the parking lot of a shopping center and was nearly boxed in by the various police vehicles.

src_legal: Respondent evaded the trap by making a sharp turn, colliding with Scott's police car, exiting the parking lot, and speeding off once again down a two-lane highway.
tgt_plain: The defendant avoided the trap by making a sharp turn, colliding with Scott's police car, exiting the parking lot, and speeding off once again down a two-lane highway.

src_legal: Following respondent's shopping center maneuvering, which resulted in slight damage to Scott's police car, Scott took over as the lead pursuit vehicle.
tgt_plain: Following the defendant's shopping center maneuvering, which resulted in slight damage to Scott's police car, Scott took over as the lead chase vehicle.

src_legal: Six minutes and nearly 10 miles after the chase had begun, Scott decided to attempt to terminate the episode by employing a "Precision Intervention Technique ('PIT') maneuver, which causes the fleeing vehicle to spin to a stop."
tgt_plain: Six minutes and nearly 10 miles after the chase had begun, Scott decided to attempt to end the episode by using a "Precision Intervention Technique ('PIT') maneuver, which causes the fleeing vehicle to spin to a stop."

src_legal: Instead, Scott applied his push bumper to the rear of respondent's vehicle. As a result, respondent lost control of his vehicle, which left the roadway, ran down an embankment, overturned, and crashed.
tgt_plain: Instead, Scott applied his push bumper to the rear of the defendant's vehicle. As a result, the defendant lost control of his vehicle, which left the roadway, ran down an embankment, overturned, and crashed.

src_legal: Respondent was badly injured and was rendered a quadriplegic.
tgt_plain: The defendant was badly injured and became a quadriplegic.

src_legal: Respondent filed suit against Deputy Scott and others under Rev. Stat. § 1979, 42 U.S.C. § 1983, alleging, inter alia, a violation of his federal constitutional rights, viz. use of excessive force resulting in an unreasonable seizure under the Fourth Amendment.
tgt_plain: The defendant filed a lawsuit against Deputy Scott and others under Revised Statutes section 1979, Title 42 of the United States Code section 1983, claiming, among other things, a violation of his federal constitutional rights, namely use of excessive force resulting in an unreasonable seizure under the Fourth Amendment.

src_legal: In response, Scott filed a motion for summary judgment based on an assertion of qualified immunity.
tgt_plain: In response, Scott filed a request for a decision without trial based on a claim of limited protection from lawsuits.

src_legal: In resolving questions of qualified immunity, courts are required to resolve a "threshold question: Taken in the light most favorable to the party asserting the injury, do the facts alleged show the officer's conduct violated a constitutional right."
tgt_plain: In resolving questions of limited protection from lawsuits, courts are required to resolve a "threshold question: Viewing the facts in favor of the person claiming the injury, do the facts claimed show the officer's conduct violated a constitutional right."

src_legal: If, and only if, the court finds a violation of a constitutional right, "the next, sequential step is to ask whether the right was clearly established in light of the specific context of the case."
tgt_plain: If, and only if, the court finds a violation of a constitutional right, "the next step is to ask whether the right was clearly established considering the specific context of the case."

src_legal: The first step in assessing the constitutionality of Scott's actions is to determine the relevant facts.
tgt_plain: The first step in evaluating the constitutionality of Scott's actions is to determine the relevant facts.

src_legal: As this case was decided on summary judgment, there have not yet been factual findings by a judge or jury, and respondent's version of events (unsurprisingly) differs substantially from Scott's version.
tgt_plain: As this case was decided on a motion for decision without trial, there have not yet been factual findings by a judge or jury, and the defendant's version of events (unsurprisingly) differs substantially from Scott's version.

src_legal: When things are in such a posture, courts are required to view the facts and draw reasonable inferences "in the light most favorable to the party opposing the motion."
tgt_plain: When things are in such a situation, courts are required to view the facts and draw reasonable inferences "in the light most favorable to the party opposing the motion."

src_legal: In qualified immunity cases, this usually means adopting (as the Court of Appeals did here) the plaintiff's version of the facts.
tgt_plain: In limited protection from lawsuit cases, this usually means adopting (as the Court of Appeals did here) the complainant's version of the facts.

src_legal: The videotape quite clearly contradicts the version of the story told by respondent and adopted by the Court of Appeals.
tgt_plain: The video recording quite clearly contradicts the version of the story told by the defendant and adopted by the Court of Appeals.

src_legal: For example, the Court of Appeals adopted respondent's assertions that, during the chase, "there was little, if any, actual threat to pedestrians or other motorists, as the roads were mostly empty and respondent remained in control of his vehicle."
tgt_plain: For example, the Court of Appeals adopted the defendant's claims that, during the chase, "there was little, if any, actual threat to pedestrians or other drivers, as the roads were mostly empty and the defendant remained in control of his vehicle."

src_legal: Indeed, reading the lower court's opinion, one gets the impression that respondent, rather than fleeing from police, was attempting to pass his driving test.
tgt_plain: Indeed, reading the lower court's opinion, one gets the impression that the defendant, rather than fleeing from police, was attempting to pass his driving test.

src_legal: Taking the facts from the non-movant's viewpoint, respondent remained in control of his vehicle, slowed for turns and intersections, and typically used his indicators for turns.
tgt_plain: Taking the facts from the person not making the motion's viewpoint, the defendant remained in control of his vehicle, slowed for turns and intersections, and typically used his turn signals for turns.

src_legal: Significantly, by the time the parties were back on the highway and Scott rammed respondent, the motorway had been cleared of motorists and pedestrians allegedly because of police blockades of the nearby intersections.
tgt_plain: Significantly, by the time the parties were back on the highway and Scott rammed the defendant, the motorway had been cleared of drivers and pedestrians supposedly because of police blockades of the nearby intersections.

src_legal: There we see respondent's vehicle racing down narrow, two-lane roads in the dead of night at speeds that are shockingly fast.
tgt_plain: There we see the defendant's vehicle racing down narrow, two-lane roads in the dead of night at speeds that are shockingly fast.

src_legal: Far from being the cautious and controlled driver the lower court depicts, what we see on the video more closely resembles a Hollywood-style car chase of the most frightening sort, placing police officers and innocent bystanders alike at great risk of serious injury.
tgt_plain: Far from being the cautious and controlled driver the lower court depicts, what we see on the video more closely resembles a Hollywood-style car chase of the most frightening kind, placing police officers and innocent bystanders alike at great risk of serious injury.

src_legal: That was the case here with regard to the factual issue whether respondent was driving in such fashion as to endanger human life.
tgt_plain: That was the case here regarding the factual issue whether the defendant was driving in such a way as to endanger human life.

src_legal: Respondent's version of events is so utterly discredited by the record that no reasonable jury could have believed him.
tgt_plain: The defendant's version of events is so completely discredited by the record that no reasonable jury could have believed him.

src_legal: The Court of Appeals should not have relied on such visible fiction; it should have viewed the facts in the light depicted by the videotape.
tgt_plain: The Court of Appeals should not have relied on such obvious fiction; it should have viewed the facts in the light shown by the video recording.

src_legal: Judging the matter on that basis, we think it is quite clear that Deputy Scott did not violate the Fourth Amendment.
tgt_plain: Judging the matter on that basis, we think it is quite clear that Deputy Scott did not violate the Fourth Amendment protection against unreasonable searches and seizures.

src_legal: Scott does not contest that his decision to terminate the car chase by ramming his bumper into respondent's vehicle constituted a "seizure."
tgt_plain: Scott does not dispute that his decision to end the car chase by ramming his bumper into the defendant's vehicle constituted a "seizure."

src_legal: The question we need to answer is whether Scott's actions were objectively reasonable.
tgt_plain: The question we need to answer is whether Scott's actions were objectively reasonable.

src_legal: In determining the reasonableness of the manner in which a seizure is effected, we must balance the nature and quality of the intrusion on the individual's Fourth Amendment interests against the importance of the governmental interests alleged to justify the intrusion.
tgt_plain: In determining the reasonableness of the manner in which a seizure is carried out, we must balance the nature and quality of the intrusion on the individual's Fourth Amendment interests against the importance of the governmental interests claimed to justify the intrusion.

src_legal: Scott defends his actions by pointing to the paramount governmental interest in ensuring public safety, and respondent nowhere suggests this was not the purpose motivating Scott's behavior.
tgt_plain: Scott defends his actions by pointing to the supreme governmental interest in ensuring public safety, and the defendant nowhere suggests this was not the purpose motivating Scott's behavior.

src_legal: Thus, in judging whether Scott's actions were reasonable, we must consider the risk of bodily harm that Scott's actions posed to respondent in light of the threat to the public that Scott was trying to eliminate.
tgt_plain: Thus, in judging whether Scott's actions were reasonable, we must consider the risk of bodily harm that Scott's actions posed to the defendant in light of the threat to the public that Scott was trying to eliminate.

src_legal: Although there is no obvious way to quantify the risks on either side, it is clear from the videotape that respondent posed an actual and imminent threat to the lives of any pedestrians who might have been present, to other civilian motorists, and to the officers involved in the chase.
tgt_plain: Although there is no obvious way to measure the risks on either side, it is clear from the video recording that the defendant posed an actual and immediate threat to the lives of any pedestrians who might have been present, to other civilian drivers, and to the officers involved in the chase.

src_legal: It is equally clear that Scott's actions posed a high likelihood of serious injury or death to respondent—though not the near certainty of death posed by, say, shooting a fleeing felon in the back of the head, or pulling alongside a fleeing motorist's car and shooting the motorist.
tgt_plain: It is equally clear that Scott's actions posed a high likelihood of serious injury or death to the defendant—though not the near certainty of death posed by, say, shooting a fleeing criminal in the back of the head, or pulling alongside a fleeing driver's car and shooting the driver.

src_legal: But wait, says respondent: Couldn't the innocent public equally have been protected, and the tragic accident entirely avoided, if the police had simply ceased their pursuit?
tgt_plain: But wait, says the defendant: Couldn't the innocent public equally have been protected, and the tragic accident entirely avoided, if the police had simply stopped their pursuit?

src_legal: We think the police need not have taken that chance and hoped for the best.
tgt_plain: We think the police did not need to take that chance and hope for the best.

src_legal: Whereas Scott's action—ramming respondent off the road—was certain to eliminate the risk that respondent posed to the public, ceasing pursuit was not.
tgt_plain: Whereas Scott's action—ramming the defendant off the road—was certain to eliminate the risk that the defendant posed to the public, stopping pursuit was not.

src_legal: First of all, there would have been no way to convey convincingly to respondent that the chase was off, and that he was free to go.
tgt_plain: First of all, there would have been no way to communicate convincingly to the defendant that the chase was off, and that he was free to go.

src_legal: Had respondent looked in his rear-view mirror and seen the police cars deactivate their flashing lights and turn around, he would have had no idea whether they were truly letting him get away, or simply devising a new strategy for capture.
tgt_plain: Had the defendant looked in his rear-view mirror and seen the police cars turn off their flashing lights and turn around, he would have had no idea whether they were truly letting him get away, or simply devising a new strategy for capture.

src_legal: Given such uncertainty, respondent might have been just as likely to respond by continuing to drive recklessly as by slowing down and wiping his brow.
tgt_plain: Given such uncertainty, the defendant might have been just as likely to respond by continuing to drive recklessly as by slowing down and wiping his brow.

src_legal: The Constitution assuredly does not impose this invitation to impunity-earned-by-recklessness.
tgt_plain: The Constitution certainly does not impose this invitation to freedom from punishment earned by recklessness.

src_legal: Instead, we lay down a more sensible rule: A police officer's attempt to terminate a dangerous high-speed car chase that threatens the lives of innocent bystanders does not violate the Fourth Amendment, even when it places the fleeing motorist at risk of serious injury or death.
tgt_plain: Instead, we establish a more sensible rule: A police officer's attempt to end a dangerous high-speed car chase that threatens the lives of innocent bystanders does not violate the Fourth Amendment protection against unreasonable searches and seizures, even when it places the fleeing driver at risk of serious injury or death.

src_legal: The car chase that respondent initiated in this case posed a substantial and immediate risk of serious physical injury to others; no reasonable jury could conclude otherwise.

src_legal: The general scheme of the Agricultural Adjustment Act of 1938 as related to wheat is to control the volume moving in interstate and foreign commerce in order to avoid surpluses and shortages and the consequent abnormally low or high wheat prices and obstructions to commerce.
tgt_plain: The general plan of the Agricultural Adjustment Act of 1938 as related to wheat is to control the volume moving in commerce between states and foreign commerce in order to avoid surpluses and shortages and the resulting abnormally low or high wheat prices and obstructions to commerce.

src_legal: Within prescribed limits and by prescribed standards the Secretary of Agriculture is directed to ascertain and proclaim each year a national acreage allotment for the next crop of wheat, which is then apportioned to the states and their counties, and is eventually broken up into allotments for individual farms.
tgt_plain: Within established limits and by established standards the Secretary of Agriculture is directed to determine and announce each year a national acreage allotment for the next crop of wheat, which is then distributed to the states and their counties, and is eventually broken up into allotments for individual farms.

src_legal: The Act provides further that whenever it appears that the total supply of wheat as of the beginning of any marketing year, beginning July 1, will exceed a normal year's domestic consumption and export by more than 35 per cent, the Secretary shall so proclaim not later than May 15 prior to the beginning of such marketing year.

src_legal: In answer the Government argues that the statute regulates neither production nor consumption, but only marketing; and, in the alternative, that if the Act does go beyond the regulation of marketing it is sustainable as a 'necessary and proper' implementation of the power of Congress over interstate commerce.
tgt_plain: In answer the Government argues that the statute regulates neither production nor consumption, but only marketing; and, in the alternative, that if the Act does go beyond the regulation of marketing it is sustainable as a 'necessary and proper' implementation of the power of Congress over commerce between states.

src_legal: The Government's concern lest the Act be held to be a regulation of production or consumption rather than of marketing is attributable to a few dicta and decisions of this Court which might be understood to lay it down that activities such as 'production,' 'manufacturing,' and 'mining' are strictly 'local.'
tgt_plain: The Government's concern that the Act be held to be a regulation of production or consumption rather than of marketing is attributable to a few statements and decisions of this Court which might be understood to establish that activities such as 'production,' 'manufacturing,' and 'mining' are strictly 'local.'

src_legal: Even today, when this power has been held to have great latitude, there is no decision of this Court that such activities may be regulated where no part of the product is intended for interstate commerce or intermingled with the subjects thereof.
tgt_plain: Even today, when this power has been held to have great flexibility, there is no decision of this Court that such activities may be regulated where no part of the product is intended for commerce between states or mixed with the subjects thereof.

src_legal: We believe that a review of the course of decision under the Commerce Clause will make plain, however, that questions of the power of Congress are not to be decided by reference to any formula which would give controlling force to nomenclature such as 'production' and 'indirect' and foreclose consideration of the actual effects of the activity in question upon interstate commerce.
tgt_plain: We believe that a review of the course of decision under the Commerce Clause will make clear, however, that questions of the power of Congress are not to be decided by reference to any formula which would give controlling force to terminology such as 'production' and 'indirect' and prevent consideration of the actual effects of the activity in question upon commerce between states.

src_legal: For nearly a century, however, decisions of this Court under the Commerce Clause dealt rarely with questions of what Congress might do in the exercise of its granted power under the Clause and almost entirely with the permissibility of state activity which it was claimed discriminated against or burdened interstate commerce.
tgt_plain: For nearly a century, however, decisions of this Court under the Commerce Clause dealt rarely with questions of what Congress might do in the exercise of its granted power under the Clause and almost entirely with the permissibility of state activity which it was claimed discriminated against or burdened commerce between states.

src_legal: It was not until 1887 with the enactment of the Interstate Commerce Act that the interstate commerce power began to exert positive influence in American law and life.
tgt_plain: It was not until 1887 with the passage of the Interstate Commerce Act that the commerce between states power began to exert positive influence in American law and life.

src_legal: This first important federal resort to the commerce power was followed in 1890 by the Sherman Anti-Trust Act and, thereafter, mainly after 1903, by many others.
tgt_plain: This first important federal use of the commerce power was followed in 1890 by the Sherman Anti-Trust Act and, thereafter, mainly after 1903, by many others.

src_legal: Justice Holmes, in sustaining the exercise of national power over intrastate activity, stated for the Court that 'commerce among the states is not a technical legal conception, but a practical one, drawn from the course of business.'
tgt_plain: Justice Holmes, in upholding the exercise of national power over activity within a state, stated for the Court that 'commerce among the states is not a technical legal conception, but a practical one, drawn from the course of business.'

src_legal: It was soon demonstrated that the effects of many kinds of intrastate activity upon interstate commerce were such as to make them a proper subject of federal regulation.
tgt_plain: It was soon demonstrated that the effects of many kinds of activity within a state upon commerce between states were such as to make them a proper subject of federal regulation.

src_legal: The Court held that railroad rates of an admittedly intrastate character and fixed by authority of the state might, nevertheless, be revised by the Federal Government because of the economic effects which they had upon interstate commerce.
tgt_plain: The Court held that railroad rates of an admittedly within-state character and fixed by authority of the state might, nevertheless, be revised by the Federal Government because of the economic effects which they had upon commerce between states.

src_legal: Justice Hughes found federal intervention constitutionally authorized because of 'matters having such a close and substantial relation to interstate traffic that the control is essential or appropriate to the security of that traffic, to the efficiency of the interstate service, and to the maintenance of the conditions under which interstate commerce may be conducted upon fair terms and without molestation or hindrance.'
tgt_plain: Justice Hughes found federal intervention constitutionally authorized because of 'matters having such a close and substantial relation to traffic between states that the control is essential or appropriate to the security of that traffic, to the efficiency of the service between states, and to the maintenance of the conditions under which commerce between states may be conducted upon fair terms and without interference or hindrance.'

src_legal: The Court's recognition of the relevance of the economic effects in the application of the Commerce Clause.
tgt_plain: The Court's recognition of the relevance of the economic effects in the application of the Commerce Clause.

src_legal: Once an economic measure of the reach of the power granted to Congress in the Commerce Clause is accepted, questions of federal power cannot be decided simply by finding the activity in question to be 'production' nor can consideration of its economic effects be foreclosed by calling them 'indirect.'
tgt_plain: Once an economic measure of the reach of the power granted to Congress in the Commerce Clause is accepted, questions of federal power cannot be decided simply by finding the activity in question to be 'production' nor can consideration of its economic effects be prevented by calling them 'indirect.'

src_legal: Whether the subject of the regulation in question was 'production,' 'consumption,' or 'marketing' is, therefore, not material for purposes of deciding the question of federal power before us.
tgt_plain: Whether the subject of the regulation in question was 'production,' 'consumption,' or 'marketing' is, therefore, not relevant for purposes of deciding the question of federal power before us.

src_legal: That an activity is of local character may help in a doubtful case to determine whether Congress intended to reach it.
tgt_plain: That an activity is of local character may help in a doubtful case to determine whether Congress intended to reach it.

src_legal: But even if appellee's activity be local and though it may not be regarded as commerce, it may still, whatever its nature, be reached by Congress if it exerts a substantial economic effect on interstate commerce and this irrespective of whether such effect is what might at some earlier time have been defined as 'direct' or 'indirect.'
tgt_plain: But even if the person appealing's activity be local and though it may not be regarded as commerce, it may still, whatever its nature, be reached by Congress if it exerts a substantial economic effect on commerce between states and this regardless of whether such effect is what might at some earlier time have been defined as 'direct' or 'indirect.'

src_legal: The effect of the statute before us is to restrict the amount which may be produced for market and the extent as well to which one may forestall resort to the market by producing to meet his own needs.

src_legal: It has been his practice to raise a small acreage of winter wheat, sown in the Fall and harvested in the following July; to sell a portion of the crop; to feed part to poultry and livestock on the farm, some of which is sold; to use some in making flour for home consumption; and to keep the rest for the following seeding.

src_legal: The general scheme of the Agricultural Adjustment Act of 1938 as related to wheat is to control the volume moving in interstate and foreign commerce in order to avoid surpluses and shortages and the consequent abnormally low or high wheat prices and obstructions to commerce.
tgt_plain: The general plan of the Agricultural Adjustment Act of 1938 as related to wheat is to control the volume moving in commerce between states and foreign commerce in order to avoid surpluses and shortages and the resulting abnormally low or high wheat prices and obstructions to commerce.

src_legal: Within prescribed limits and by prescribed standards the Secretary of Agriculture is directed to ascertain and proclaim each year a national acreage allotment for the next crop of wheat, which is then apportioned to the states and their counties, and is eventually broken up into allotments for individual farms.
tgt_plain: Within established limits and by established standards the Secretary of Agriculture is directed to determine and announce each year a national acreage allotment for the next crop of wheat, which is then distributed to the states and their counties, and is eventually broken up into allotments for individual farms.

src_legal: But even if appellee's activity be local and though it may not be regarded as commerce, it may still, whatever its nature, be reached by Congress if it exerts a substantial economic effect on interstate commerce and this irrespective of whether such effect is what might at some earlier time have been defined as 'direct' or 'indirect.'
tgt_plain: But even if the person appealing's activity be local and though it may not be regarded as commerce, it may still, whatever its nature, be reached by Congress if it exerts a substantial economic effect on commerce between states and this regardless of whether such effect is what might at some earlier time have been defined as 'direct' or 'indirect.'

src_legal: Many countries, both importing and exporting, have sought to modify the impact of the world market conditions on their own economy.
tgt_plain: Many countries, both importing and exporting, have sought to change the impact of the world market conditions on their own economy.

src_legal: In the absence of regulation the price of wheat in the United States would be much affected by world conditions.
tgt_plain: In the absence of regulation the price of wheat in the United States would be much affected by world conditions.

src_legal: The effect of consumption of homegrown wheat on interstate commerce is due to the fact that it constitutes the most variable factor in the disappearance of the wheat crop.
tgt_plain: The effect of consumption of homegrown wheat on commerce between states is due to the fact that it constitutes the most variable factor in the disappearance of the wheat crop.

src_legal: The maintenance by government regulation of a price for wheat undoubtedly can be accomplished as effectively by sustaining or increasing the demand as by limiting the supply.
tgt_plain: The maintenance by government regulation of a price for wheat undoubtedly can be accomplished as effectively by supporting or increasing the demand as by limiting the supply.

src_legal: The effect of the statute before us is to restrict the amount which may be produced for market and the extent as well to which one may forestall resort to the market by producing to meet his own needs.
tgt_plain: The effect of the statute before us is to restrict the amount which may be produced for market and the extent as well to which one may prevent the need to go to the market by producing to meet his own needs.

src_legal: That appellee's own contribution to the demand for wheat may be trivial by itself is not enough to remove him from the scope of federal regulation where, as here, his contribution, taken together with that of many others similarly situated, is far from trivial.
tgt_plain: That the person appealing's own contribution to the demand for wheat may be trivial by itself is not enough to remove him from the scope of federal regulation where, as here, his contribution, taken together with that of many others similarly situated, is far from trivial.

tgt_plain: It is well established by decisions of this Court that the power to regulate commerce includes the power to regulate the prices at which goods in that commerce are dealt in and practices affecting such prices.

src_legal: The distinction between a direct and an indirect effect turns, not upon the magnitude of either the cause or the effect, but entirely upon the manner in which the effect has been brought about.
tgt_plain: The distinction between a direct and an indirect effect turns not upon the size of either the cause or the effect, but entirely upon the manner in which the effect has been brought about.

src_legal: The matter of degree has no bearing upon the question here, since that question is not what is the extent of the local activity or condition, or the extent of the effect produced upon interstate commerce, but what is the relation between the activity or condition and the effect.

src_legal: The defendant willfully conspired to have printed and circulated to men who had been called and accepted for military service a document set forth and alleged to be calculated to cause such insubordination and obstruction.
tgt_plain: The defendant intentionally conspired to have printed and circulated to men who had been called and accepted for military service a document set forth and claimed to be calculated to cause such disobedience and obstruction.

src_legal: The count alleges overt acts in pursuance of the conspiracy, ending in the distribution of the document set forth.

src_legal: On the morning of March 31, 1966, David Paul O'Brien and three companions burned their Selective Service registration certificates on the steps of the South Boston Courthouse.
tgt_plain: On the morning of March 31, 1966, David Paul O'Brien and three companions burned their Selective Service registration certificates on the steps of the South Boston Courthouse.

src_legal: A sizable crowd, including several agents of the Federal Bureau of Investigation, witnessed the event.
tgt_plain: A large crowd, including several agents of the Federal Bureau of Investigation, witnessed the event.

src_legal: An FBI agent ushered O'Brien to safety inside the courthouse.
tgt_plain: An FBI agent escorted O'Brien to safety inside the courthouse.

src_legal: After he was advised of his right to counsel and to silence, O'Brien stated to FBI agents that he had burned his registration certificate because of his beliefs, knowing that he was violating federal law.
tgt_plain: After he was advised of his right to a lawyer and to silence, O'Brien stated to FBI agents that he had burned his registration certificate because of his beliefs, knowing that he was violating federal law.

src_legal: For this act, O'Brien was indicted, tried, convicted, and sentenced in the United States District Court for the District of Massachusetts.
tgt_plain: For this act, O'Brien was charged, tried, convicted, and sentenced in the United States District Court for the District of Massachusetts.

src_legal: He stated in argument to the jury that he burned the certificate publicly to influence others to adopt his antiwar beliefs, as he put it, 'so that other people would reevaluate their positions with Selective Service, with the armed forces, and reevaluate their place in the culture of today, to hopefully consider my position.'
tgt_plain: He stated in argument to the jury that he burned the certificate publicly to influence others to adopt his antiwar beliefs, as he put it, 'so that other people would rethink their positions with Selective Service, with the armed forces, and rethink their place in the culture of today, to hopefully consider my position.'

src_legal: The indictment upon which he was tried charged that he 'willfully and knowingly did multilate, destroy, and change by burning his Registration Certificate in violation of Title 50, App., United States Code, Section 462(b).'
tgt_plain: The indictment upon which he was tried charged that he 'intentionally and knowingly did mutilate, destroy, and change by burning his Registration Certificate in violation of Title 50, Appendix, United States Code, Section 462(b).'

src_legal: By the 1965 Amendment, Congress added to § 12(b)(3) of the 1948 Act the provision here at issue, subjecting to criminal liability not only one who 'forges, alters, or in any manner changes' but also one who 'knowingly destroys (or) knowingly mutilates' a certificate.
tgt_plain: By the 1965 Amendment, Congress added to section 12(b)(3) of the 1948 Act the provision here at issue, subjecting to criminal liability not only one who 'forges, alters, or in any manner changes' but also one who 'knowingly destroys (or) knowingly mutilates' a certificate.

src_legal: We note at the outset that the 1965 Amendment plainly does not abridge free speech on its face, and we do not understand O'Brien to argue otherwise.
tgt_plain: We note at the outset that the 1965 Amendment plainly does not reduce free speech on its face, and we do not understand O'Brien to argue otherwise.

src_legal: The Amendment does not distinguish between public and private destruction, and it does not punish only destruction engaged in for the purpose of expressing views.
tgt_plain: The Amendment does not distinguish between public and private destruction, and it does not punish only destruction engaged in for the purpose of expressing views.

src_legal: A law prohibiting destruction of Selective Service certificates no more abridges free speech on its face than a motor vehicle law prohibiting the destruction of drivers' licenses, or a tax law prohibiting the destruction of books and records.
tgt_plain: A law prohibiting destruction of Selective Service certificates no more reduces free speech on its face than a motor vehicle law prohibiting the destruction of drivers' licenses, or a tax law prohibiting the destruction of books and records.

src_legal: O'Brien nonetheless argues that the 1965 Amendment is unconstitutional in its application to him, and is unconstitutional as enacted because what he calls the 'purpose' of Congress was 'to suppress freedom of speech.'
tgt_plain: O'Brien nonetheless argues that the 1965 Amendment is unconstitutional in its application to him, and is unconstitutional as passed because what he calls the 'purpose' of Congress was 'to suppress freedom of speech.'

src_legal: O'Brien first argues that the 1965 Amendment is unconstitutional as applied to him because his act of burning his registration certificate was protected 'symbolic speech' within the First Amendment.
tgt_plain: O'Brien first argues that the 1965 Amendment is unconstitutional as applied to him because his act of burning his registration certificate was protected 'symbolic speech' within the First Amendment.

src_legal: His argument is that the freedom of expression which the First Amendment guarantees includes all modes of 'communication of ideas by conduct,' and that his conduct is within this definition because he did it in 'demonstration against the war and against the draft.'
tgt_plain: His argument is that the freedom of expression which the First Amendment guarantees includes all modes of 'communication of ideas by conduct,' and that his conduct is within this definition because he did it in 'demonstration against the war and against the draft.'

src_legal: However, even on the assumption that the alleged communicative element in O'Brien's conduct is sufficient to bring into play the First Amendment, it does not necessarily follow that the destruction of a registration certificate is constitutionally protected activity.
tgt_plain: However, even on the assumption that the claimed communicative element in O'Brien's conduct is sufficient to bring into play the First Amendment, it does not necessarily follow that the destruction of a registration certificate is constitutionally protected activity.

src_legal: This Court has held that when 'speech' and 'nonspeech' elements are combined in the same course of conduct, a sufficiently important governmental interest in regulating the nonspeech element can justify incidental limitations on First Amendment freedoms.
tgt_plain: This Court has held that when 'speech' and 'nonspeech' elements are combined in the same course of conduct, a sufficiently important governmental interest in regulating the nonspeech element can justify incidental limitations on First Amendment freedoms.

src_legal: To characterize the quality of the governmental interest which must appear, the Court has employed a variety of descriptive terms: compelling; substantial; subordinating; paramount; cogent; strong.
tgt_plain: To describe the quality of the governmental interest which must appear, the Court has used a variety of descriptive terms: compelling; substantial; subordinating; paramount; persuasive; strong.

src_legal: Whatever imprecision inheres in these terms, we think it clear that a government regulation is sufficiently justified if it is within the constitutional power of the Government; if it furthers an important or substantial governmental interest; if the governmental interest is unrelated to the suppression of free expression; and if the incidental restriction on alleged First Amendment freedoms is no greater than is essential to the furtherance of that interest.
tgt_plain: Whatever imprecision exists in these terms, we think it clear that a government regulation is sufficiently justified if it is within the constitutional power of the Government; if it furthers an important or substantial governmental interest; if the governmental interest is unrelated to the suppression of free expression; and if the incidental restriction on claimed First Amendment freedoms is no greater than is essential to the advancement of that interest.

src_legal: We find that the 1965 Amendment to § 12(b)(3) of the Universal Military Training and Service Act meets all of these requirements, and consequently that O'Brien can be constitutionally convicted for violating it.
tgt_plain: We find that the 1965 Amendment to section 12(b)(3) of the Universal Military Training and Service Act meets all of these requirements, and consequently that O'Brien can be constitutionally convicted for violating it.

src_legal: The constitutional power of Congress to raise and support armies and to make all laws necessary and proper to that end is broad and sweeping.
tgt_plain: The constitutional power of Congress to raise and support armies and to make all laws necessary and proper to that end is broad and sweeping.

src_legal: O'Brien's argument to the contrary is necessarily premised upon his unrealistic characterization of Selective Service certificates.
tgt_plain: O'Brien's argument to the contrary is necessarily based upon his unrealistic characterization of Selective Service certificates.

src_legal: O'Brien notes that most of the information on a registration certificate serves no notification purpose at all; the registrant hardly needs to be told his address and physical characteristics.
tgt_plain: O'Brien notes that most of the information on a registration certificate serves no notification purpose at all; the registrant hardly needs to be told his address and physical characteristics.

src_legal: Voluntarily displaying the two certificates is an easy and painless way for a young man to dispel a question as to whether he might be delinquent in his Selective Service obligations.
tgt_plain: Voluntarily displaying the two certificates is an easy and painless way for a young man to dispel a question as to whether he might be behind in his Selective Service obligations.

tgt_plain: It is in the interest of the just and efficient administration of the system that they be continually available, in the event, for example, of a mix-up in the registrant's file.

src_legal: And we are unpersuaded that the pre-existence of the nonpossession regulations in any way negates this interest.
tgt_plain: And we are unconvinced that the pre-existence of the nonpossession regulations in any way negates this interest.

src_legal: Whoever places on public or private property a symbol, object, appellation, characterization or graffiti, including, but not limited to, a burning cross or Nazi swastika, which one knows or has reasonable grounds to know arouses anger, alarm or resentment in others on the basis of race, color, creed, religion or gender commits disorderly conduct and shall be guilty of a misdemeanor.
tgt_plain: Whoever places on public or private property a symbol, object, name, characterization or graffiti, including, but not limited to, a burning cross or Nazi swastika, which one knows or has reasonable grounds to know arouses anger, alarm or resentment in others on the basis of race, color, creed, religion or gender commits disorderly conduct and shall be guilty of a misdemeanor.

src_legal: Petitioner moved to dismiss this count on the ground that the St. Paul ordinance was substantially overbroad and impermissibly content-based and therefore facially invalid under the First Amendment.
tgt_plain: The petitioner requested to dismiss this count on the ground that the St. Paul ordinance was substantially overbroad and impermissibly content-based and therefore facially invalid under the First Amendment.

src_legal: The trial court granted this motion, but the Minnesota Supreme Court reversed.
tgt_plain: The trial court granted this request, but the Minnesota Supreme Court reversed.

src_legal: That court rejected petitioner's overbreadth claim because, as construed in prior Minnesota cases, the modifying phrase "arouses anger, alarm or resentment in others" limited the reach of the ordinance to conduct that amounts to "fighting words."
tgt_plain: That court rejected the petitioner's overbreadth claim because, as interpreted in prior Minnesota cases, the modifying phrase "arouses anger, alarm or resentment in others" limited the reach of the ordinance to conduct that amounts to "fighting words."

src_legal: The court also concluded that the ordinance was not impermissibly content-based because, in its view, "the ordinance is a narrowly tailored means toward accomplishing the compelling governmental interest in protecting the community against bias-motivated threats to public safety and order."
tgt_plain: The court also concluded that the ordinance was not impermissibly content-based because, in its view, "the ordinance is a narrowly tailored means toward accomplishing the compelling governmental interest in protecting the community against bias-motivated threats to public safety and order."

src_legal: The First Amendment generally prevents government from proscribing speech.
tgt_plain: The First Amendment generally prevents government from prohibiting speech.

src_legal: From 1791 to the present, however, our society, like other free but civilized societies, has permitted restrictions upon the content of speech in a few limited areas.
tgt_plain: From 1791 to the present, however, our society, like other free but civilized societies, has permitted restrictions upon the content of speech in a few limited areas.

src_legal: We have recognized that "the freedom of speech" referred to by the First Amendment does not include a freedom to disregard these traditional limitations.
tgt_plain: We have recognized that "the freedom of speech" referred to by the First Amendment does not include a freedom to ignore these traditional limitations.

src_legal: Our decisions since the 1960's have narrowed the scope of the traditional categorical exceptions for defamation.
tgt_plain: Our decisions since the 1960's have narrowed the scope of the traditional categorical exceptions for defamation.

src_legal: A limited categorical approach has remained an important part of our First Amendment jurisprudence.
tgt_plain: A limited categorical approach has remained an important part of our First Amendment legal philosophy.

src_legal: We have sometimes said that these categories of expression are "not within the area of constitutionally protected speech."
tgt_plain: We have sometimes said that these categories of expression are "not within the area of constitutionally protected speech."

src_legal: Such statements must be taken in context, however, and are no more literally true than is the occasionally repeated shorthand characterizing obscenity "as not being speech at all."
tgt_plain: Such statements must be taken in context, however, and are no more literally true than is the occasionally repeated shorthand describing obscenity "as not being speech at all."

src_legal: What they mean is that these areas of speech can, consistently with the First Amendment, be regulated because of their constitutionally proscribable content (obscenity, defamation, etc.)—not that they are categories of speech entirely invisible to the Constitution.
tgt_plain: What they mean is that these areas of speech can, consistently with the First Amendment, be regulated because of their constitutionally prohibitable content (obscenity, defamation, etc.)—not that they are categories of speech entirely invisible to the Constitution.

src_legal: We conclude that, even as narrowly construed by the Minnesota Supreme Court, the ordinance is facially unconstitutional.
tgt_plain: We conclude that, even as narrowly interpreted by the Minnesota Supreme Court, the ordinance is facially unconstitutional.

src_legal: Although the phrase in the ordinance, "arouses anger, alarm or resentment in others," has been limited by the Minnesota Supreme Court's construction to reach only those symbols or displays that amount to "fighting words," the remaining, unmodified terms make clear that the ordinance applies only to "fighting words" that insult, or provoke violence, "on the basis of race, color, creed, religion or gender."
tgt_plain: Although the phrase in the ordinance, "arouses anger, alarm or resentment in others," has been limited by the Minnesota Supreme Court's interpretation to reach only those symbols or displays that amount to "fighting words," the remaining, unmodified terms make clear that the ordinance applies only to "fighting words" that insult, or provoke violence, "on the basis of race, color, creed, religion or gender."

src_legal: Displays containing abusive invective, no matter how vicious or severe, are permissible unless they are addressed to one of the specified disfavored topics.
tgt_plain: Displays containing abusive language, no matter how vicious or severe, are permissible unless they are addressed to one of the specified disfavored topics.

src_legal: In its practical operation, moreover, the ordinance goes even beyond mere content discrimination, to actual viewpoint discrimination.
tgt_plain: In its practical operation, moreover, the ordinance goes even beyond mere content discrimination, to actual viewpoint discrimination.

src_legal: This Court ordinarily is not so eager to abandon its precedents.
tgt_plain: This Court ordinarily is not so eager to abandon its precedents.

src_legal: Twice within the past month, the Court has declined to overturn longstanding but controversial decisions on questions of constitutional law.

src_legal: In each case, we had the benefit of full briefing on the critical issue, so that the parties and amici had the opportunity to apprise us of the impact of a change in the law.
tgt_plain: In each case, we had the benefit of full briefing on the critical issue, so that the parties and friends of the court had the opportunity to inform us of the impact of a change in the law.

src_legal: And in each case, the Court declined to abandon its precedents, invoking the principle of stare decisis.
tgt_plain: And in each case, the Court declined to abandon its precedents, invoking the principle of standing by what was decided.

src_legal: But in the present case, the majority casts aside long-established First Amendment doctrine without the benefit of briefing and adopts an untried theory.

src_legal: This is hardly a judicious way of proceeding, and the Court's reasoning in reaching its result is transparently wrong.

src_legal: This Court's decisions have plainly stated that expression falling within certain limited categories so lacks the values the First Amendment was designed to protect that the Constitution affords no protection to that expression.
tgt_plain: This Court's decisions have clearly stated that expression falling within certain limited categories so lacks the values the First Amendment was designed to protect that the Constitution affords no protection to that expression.

src_legal: There are certain well-defined and narrowly limited classes of speech, the prevention and punishment of which have never been thought to raise any Constitutional problem.
tgt_plain: There are certain well-defined and narrowly limited classes of speech, the prevention and punishment of which have never been thought to raise any Constitutional problem.

src_legal: Thus, as the majority concedes, this Court has long held certain discrete categories of expression to be proscribable on the basis of their content.
tgt_plain: Thus, as the majority admits, this Court has long held certain separate categories of expression to be prohibitable on the basis of their content.

src_legal: For instance, the Court has held that the individual who falsely shouts "fire" in a crowded theatre may not claim the protection of the First Amendment.
tgt_plain: For instance, the Court has held that the individual who falsely shouts "fire" in a crowded theatre may not claim the protection of the First Amendment.

src_legal: The Court has concluded that neither child pornography, nor obscenity, is protected by the First Amendment.
tgt_plain: The Court has concluded that neither child pornography, nor obscenity, is protected by the First Amendment.

src_legal: And the Court has observed that, "leaving aside the special considerations when public officials and public figures are the target, a libelous publication is not protected by the Constitution."
tgt_plain: And the Court has observed that, "leaving aside the special considerations when public officials and public figures are the target, a libelous publication is not protected by the Constitution."

src_legal: To the contrary, those statements meant precisely what they said: The categorical approach is a firmly entrenched part of our First Amendment jurisprudence.

src_legal: Indeed, the Court reviewed the guarantees of freedom of expression in effect at the time of the ratification of the Constitution and concluded that in light of this history, it is apparent that the unconditional phrasing of the First Amendment was not intended to protect every utterance.

src_legal: Nevertheless, the majority holds that the First Amendment protects those narrow categories of expression long held to be undeserving of First Amendment protection—at least to the extent that lawmakers may not regulate some fighting words more strictly than others because of their content.
tgt_plain: Nevertheless, the majority holds that the First Amendment protects those narrow categories of expression long held to be undeserving of First Amendment protection—at least to the extent that lawmakers may not regulate some fighting words more strictly than others because of their content.

src_legal: The Court announces that such content-based distinctions violate the First Amendment because "the government may not regulate use based on hostility—or favoritism—towards the underlying message expressed."
tgt_plain: The Court announces that such content-based distinctions violate the First Amendment because "the government may not regulate use based on hostility—or favoritism—towards the underlying message expressed."

src_legal: Should the government want to criminalize certain fighting words, the Court now requires it to criminalize all fighting words.
tgt_plain: Should the government want to criminalize certain fighting words, the Court now requires it to criminalize all fighting words.

src_legal: Such a simplistic, all-or-nothing-at-all approach to First Amendment protection is at odds with common sense and with our jurisprudence as well.
tgt_plain: Such a simplistic, all-or-nothing-at-all approach to First Amendment protection is at odds with common sense and with our legal philosophy as well.

src_legal: It is inconsistent to hold that the government may proscribe an entire category of speech because the content of that speech is evil, but that the government may not treat a subset of that category differently without violating the First Amendment; the content of the subset is by definition worthless and undeserving of constitutional protection.
tgt_plain: It is inconsistent to hold that the government may prohibit an entire category of speech because the content of that speech is evil, but that the government may not treat a subset of that category differently without violating the First Amendment; the content of the subset is by definition worthless and undeserving of constitutional protection.

src_legal: Penal Code section 415 prohibits 'maliciously and willfully disturbing the peace or quiet of any neighborhood or person by offensive conduct,' for wearing a jacket bearing the words 'Fuck the Draft' in a corridor of the Los Angeles Courthouse.
tgt_plain: Penal Code section 415 prohibits 'maliciously and intentionally disturbing the peace or quiet of any neighborhood or person by offensive conduct,' for wearing a jacket bearing the words 'Fuck the Draft' in a corridor of the Los Angeles Courthouse.

src_legal: The Court of Appeal held that 'offensive conduct' means 'behavior which has a tendency to provoke others to acts of violence or to in turn disturb the peace,' and affirmed the conviction.
tgt_plain: The Court of Appeal held that 'offensive conduct' means 'behavior which has a tendency to provoke others to acts of violence or to in turn disturb the peace,' and upheld the conviction.

src_legal: Held: Absent a more particularized and compelling reason for its actions, the State may not, consistently with the First and Fourteenth Amendments, make the simple public display of this single four-letter expletive a criminal offense.
tgt_plain: Held: Absent a more specific and compelling reason for its actions, the State may not, consistently with the First and Fourteenth Amendments, make the simple public display of this single four-letter expletive a criminal offense.

src_legal: This case may seem at first blush too inconsequential to find its way into our books, but the issue it presents is of no small constitutional significance.
tgt_plain: This case may seem at first glance too unimportant to find its way into our books, but the issue it presents is of no small constitutional significance.

src_legal: Appellant Paul Robert Cohen was convicted in the Los Angeles Municipal Court of violating that part of California Penal Code section 415 which prohibits 'maliciously and willfully disturbing the peace or quiet of any neighborhood or person by offensive conduct.'
tgt_plain: Appellant Paul Robert Cohen was convicted in the Los Angeles Municipal Court of violating that part of California Penal Code section 415 which prohibits 'maliciously and intentionally disturbing the peace or quiet of any neighborhood or person by offensive conduct.'

src_legal: He was given 30 days' imprisonment.
tgt_plain: He was given 30 days in jail.

src_legal: The facts upon which his conviction rests are detailed in the opinion of the Court of Appeal of California, Second Appellate District.
tgt_plain: The facts upon which his conviction rests are detailed in the opinion of the Court of Appeal of California, Second Appellate District.

src_legal: On April 26, 1968, the defendant was observed in the Los Angeles County Courthouse in the corridor outside of division 20 of the municipal court wearing a jacket bearing the words 'Fuck the Draft' which were plainly visible.
tgt_plain: On April 26, 1968, the defendant was observed in the Los Angeles County Courthouse in the corridor outside of division 20 of the municipal court wearing a jacket bearing the words 'Fuck the Draft' which were plainly visible.

src_legal: The defendant testified that he wore the jacket knowing that the words were on the jacket as a means of informing the public of the depth of his feelings against the Vietnam War and the draft.
tgt_plain: The defendant testified that he wore the jacket knowing that the words were on the jacket as a means of informing the public of the depth of his feelings against the Vietnam War and the draft.

src_legal: The defendant did not engage in, nor threaten to engage in, nor did anyone as the result of his conduct.
tgt_plain: The defendant did not engage in, nor threaten to engage in, nor did anyone as the result of his conduct.

src_legal: The defendant did not make any loud or unusual noise, nor was there any evidence that he uttered any sound prior to his arrest.
tgt_plain: The defendant did not make any loud or unusual noise, nor was there any evidence that he uttered any sound before his arrest.

src_legal: In affirming the conviction the Court of Appeal held that 'offensive conduct' means 'behavior which has a tendency to provoke others to acts of violence or to in turn disturb the peace,' and that the State had proved this element because, on the facts of this case, 'it was certainly reasonably foreseeable that such conduct might cause others to rise up to commit a violent act against the person of the defendant or attempt to forceably remove his jacket.'
tgt_plain: In upholding the conviction the Court of Appeal held that 'offensive conduct' means 'behavior which has a tendency to provoke others to acts of violence or to in turn disturb the peace,' and that the State had proved this element because, on the facts of this case, 'it was certainly reasonably foreseeable that such conduct might cause others to rise up to commit a violent act against the person of the defendant or attempt to forcibly remove his jacket.'

src_legal: Any attempt to support this conviction on the ground that the statute seeks to preserve an appropriately decorous atmosphere in the courthouse where Cohen was arrested must fail in the absence of any language in the statute that would have put appellant on notice that certain kinds of otherwise permissible speech or conduct would nevertheless, under California law, not be tolerated in certain places.
tgt_plain: Any attempt to support this conviction on the ground that the statute seeks to preserve an appropriately respectful atmosphere in the courthouse where Cohen was arrested must fail in the absence of any language in the statute that would have put the appellant on notice that certain kinds of otherwise permissible speech or conduct would nevertheless, under California law, not be tolerated in certain places.

src_legal: And, while it may be that one has a more substantial claim to a recognizable privacy interest when walking through a courthouse corridor than, for example, strolling through Central Park, surely it is nothing like the interest in being free from unwanted expression in the confines of one's own home.

src_legal: It is whether California can excise, as 'offensive conduct,' one particular scurrilous epithet from the public discourse, either upon the theory of the court below that its use is inherently likely to cause violent reaction or upon a more general assertion that the States, acting as guardians of public morality, may properly remove this offensive word from the public vocabulary.
tgt_plain: It is whether California can remove, as 'offensive conduct,' one particular vulgar insult from the public discourse, either upon the theory of the court below that its use is inherently likely to cause violent reaction or upon a more general assertion that the States, acting as guardians of public morality, may properly remove this offensive word from the public vocabulary.

tgt_plain: There may be some persons about with such lawless and violent tendencies, but that is an insufficient base upon which to erect, consistently with constitutional values, a governmental power to force persons who wish to express their dissident views into avoiding particular forms of expression.

tgt_plain: Much linguistic expression serves a dual communicative function: it conveys not only ideas capable of relatively precise, detached explanation, but otherwise inexpressible emotions as well.

src_legal: Two federal district courts, two United States courts of appeals, and this Court—within a period of less than three weeks from inception until today—have been pressed into hurried decision of profound constitutional issues on inadequately developed and largely assumed facts without the careful deliberation that, one would hope, should characterize the American judicial process.
tgt_plain: Two federal district courts, two United States courts of appeals, and this Court—within a period of less than three weeks from start until today—have been pushed into rushed decision of deep constitutional issues on inadequately developed and largely assumed facts without the careful thought that, one would hope, should characterize the American judicial process.

src_legal: Judge Wilkey, dissenting in the District of Columbia case, after a review of only the affidavits before his court (the basic papers had not then been made available by either party), concluded that there were a number of examples of documents that, if in the possession of the Post, and if published, 'could clearly result in great harm to the nation,' and he defined 'harm' to mean 'the death of soldiers, the destruction of alliances, the greatly increased difficulty of negotiation with our enemies, the inability of our diplomats to negotiate * * *.' I, for one, have now been able to give at least some cursory study not only to the affidavits, but to the material itself.
tgt_plain: Judge Wilkey, disagreeing in the District of Columbia case, after a review of only the sworn statements before his court (the basic papers had not then been made available by either party), concluded that there were a number of examples of documents that, if in the possession of the Post, and if published, 'could clearly result in great harm to the nation,' and he defined 'harm' to mean 'the death of soldiers, the destruction of alliances, the greatly increased difficulty of negotiation with our enemies, the inability of our diplomats to negotiate.' I, for one, have now been able to give at least some brief study not only to the sworn statements, but to the material itself.

src_legal: I regreat to say that from this examination I fear that Judge Wilkey's statements have possible foundation.

src_legal: If, however, damage has been done, and if, with the Court's action today, these newspapers proceed to publish the critical documents and there results therefrom 'the death of soldiers, the destruction of alliances, the greatly increased difficulty of negotiation with our enemies, the inability of our diplomats to negotiate,' to which list I might add the factors of prolongation of the war and of further delay in the freeing of United States prisoners, then the Nation's people will know where the responsibility for these sad consequences rests.
tgt_plain: If, however, damage has been done, and if, with the Court's action today, these newspapers proceed to publish the critical documents and there results from it 'the death of soldiers, the destruction of alliances, the greatly increased difficulty of negotiation with our enemies, the inability of our diplomats to negotiate,' to which list I might add the factors of extending the war and of further delay in the freeing of United States prisoners, then the Nation's people will know where the responsibility for these sad consequences rests.

src_legal: When speaking of the Bill of Rights in the House of Representatives, Madison said: 'If they (the first ten amendments) are incorporated into the Constitution, independent tribunals of justice will consider themselves in a peculiar manner the guardians of those rights; they will be an impenetrable bulwark against every assumption of power in the Legislative or Executive; they will be naturally led to resist every encroachment upon rights expressly stipulated for in the Constitution by the declaration of rights.' 1 Annals of Cong. 439.
tgt_plain: When speaking of the Bill of Rights in the House of Representatives, Madison said: 'If they (the first ten amendments) are added to the Constitution, independent courts will consider themselves in a special manner the protectors of those rights; they will be an unbreakable barrier against every taking of power in the Legislative or Executive; they will be naturally led to resist every violation of rights clearly promised in the Constitution by the bill of rights.' 1 Annals of Cong. 439.

src_legal: Here there is no question but that the material sought to be suppressed is within the protection of the First Amendment; the only question is whether, notwithstanding that fact, its publication may be enjoined for a time because of the presence of an overwhelming national interest.
tgt_plain: Here there is no question but that the material sought to be blocked is within the protection of the First Amendment; the only question is whether, despite that fact, its publication may be stopped for a time because of the presence of an overwhelming national interest.

src_legal: '(e) Whoever having unauthorized possession of, access to, or control over any document, writing, code book, signal book, sketch, photograph, photographic negative, blueprint, plan, map, model, instrument, appliance, or note relating to the national defense, or information relating to the national defense which information the possessor has reason to believe could be used to the injury of the United States or to the advantage of any foreign nation, willfully communicates, delivers, transmits or causes to be communicated, delivered, or transmitted, or attempts to communicate, deliver, transmit or cause to be communicated, delivered, or transmitted the same to any person not entitled to receive it, or willfully retains the same and fails to deliver it to the officer or employee of the United States entitled to receive it;' is guilty of an offense punishable by 10 years in prison, a $10,000 fine, or both.
tgt_plain: '(e) Whoever having unauthorized possession of, access to, or control over any document, writing, code book, signal book, sketch, photograph, photographic negative, blueprint, plan, map, model, instrument, appliance, or note relating to the national defense, or information relating to the national defense which information the possessor has reason to believe could be used to the harm of the United States or to the advantage of any foreign nation, intentionally communicates, delivers, transmits or causes to be communicated, delivered, or transmitted, or attempts to communicate, deliver, transmit or cause to be communicated, delivered, or transmitted the same to any person not allowed to receive it, or intentionally keeps the same and fails to deliver it to the officer or employee of the United States allowed to receive it;' is guilty of an offense punishable by 10 years in jail, a $10,000 fine, or both.

src_legal: It should also be noted that 18 U.S.C. § 793(g), added in 1950 (see 64 Stat. 1004; S.Rep.No.2369, pt. 1, 81st Cong., 2d Sess., 9 (1950)), provides that '(i)f two or more persons conspire to violate any of the foregoing provisions of this section, and one or more of such persons do any act to effect the object of the conspiracy, each of the parties to such conspiracy shall be subject to the punishment provided for the offense which is the object of such conspiracy.'.
tgt_plain: It should also be noted that 18 U.S.C. § 793(g), added in 1950 (see 64 Stat. 1004; S.Rep.No.2369, pt. 1, 81st Cong., 2d Sess., 9 (1950)), provides that 'if two or more persons conspire to violate any of the earlier provisions of this section, and one or more of such persons do any act to accomplish the goal of the conspiracy, each of the parties to such conspiracy shall be subject to the punishment provided for the offense which is the goal of such conspiracy.'

src_legal: The amendment of § 793 that added subsection (e) was part of the Subversive Activities Control Act of 1950, which was in turn Title I of the Internal Security Act of 1950.
tgt_plain: The change to § 793 that added subsection (e) was part of the Subversive Activities Control Act of 1950, which was in turn Title I of the Internal Security Act of 1950.

src_legal: The report of the Senate Judiciary Committee best explains the purposes of the amendment:.
