src_legal: 'Section 18 of the bill amends section 793 of title 18 of the United States Code (espionage statute).
tgt_plain: 'Section 18 of the bill changes section 793 of title 18 of the United States Code (espionage law).

src_legal: '(1) Amends the fourth paragraph of section 793, title 18 (subsec. (d)), to cover the unlawful dissemination of 'information relating to the national defense which information the possessor has reason to believe could be used to the injury of the United States or to the advantage of any foreign nation.' The phrase 'which information the possessor has reason to believe could be used to the injury of the United States or to the advantage of any foreign nation' would modify only 'information relating to the national defense' and not the other items enumerated in the subsection.
tgt_plain: '(1) Changes the fourth paragraph of section 793, title 18 (subsec. (d)), to cover the illegal spreading of 'information relating to the national defense which information the possessor has reason to believe could be used to the harm of the United States or to the advantage of any foreign nation.' The phrase 'which information the possessor has reason to believe could be used to the harm of the United States or to the advantage of any foreign nation' would apply only to 'information relating to the national defense' and not the other items listed in the subsection.

src_legal: The fourth paragraph of section 793 is also amended to provide that only those with lawful possession of the items relating to national defense enumerated therein may retain them subject to demand therefor.
tgt_plain: The fourth paragraph of section 793 is also changed to provide that only those with legal possession of the items relating to national defense listed there may keep them subject to demand for them.

src_legal: Existing law provides no penalty for the unauthorized possession of such items unless a demand for them is made by the person entitled to receive them.
tgt_plain: Existing law provides no penalty for the unauthorized possession of such items unless a demand for them is made by the person allowed to receive them.

src_legal: The only difference between subsection (d) and subsection (e) of section 793 is that a demand by the person entitled to receive the items would be a necessary element of an offense under subsection (d) where the possession is lawful, whereas such.
tgt_plain: The only difference between subsection (d) and subsection (e) of section 793 is that a demand by the person allowed to receive the items would be a necessary element of an offense under subsection (d) where the possession is legal, whereas such demand is not needed for subsection (e).

src_legal: It seems clear from the foregoing, contrary to the intimations of the District Court for the Southern District of New York in this case, that in prosecuting for communicating or withholding a 'document' as contrasted with similar action with respect to 'information' the Government need not prove an intent to injure the United States or to benefit a foreign nation but only willful and knowing conduct.
tgt_plain: It seems clear from the above, opposite to the suggestions of the District Court for the Southern District of New York in this case, that in charging for communicating or withholding a 'document' as opposed to similar action with respect to 'information' the Government need not prove an intent to harm the United States or to benefit a foreign nation but only intentional and knowing conduct.

src_legal: Also, from the face of subsection (e) and from the context of the Act of which it was a part, it seems undeniable that a newspaper, as well as others unconnected with the Government, are vulnerable to prosecution under § 793(e) if they communicate or withhold the materials covered by that section.
tgt_plain: Also, from the face of subsection (e) and from the context of the Act of which it was a part, it seems clear that a newspaper, as well as others not connected with the Government, can be prosecuted under § 793(e) if they communicate or withhold the materials covered by that section.

src_legal: The District Court ruled that 'communication' did not reach publication by a newspaper of documents relating to the national defense.
tgt_plain: The District Court ruled that 'communication' did not include publication by a newspaper of documents relating to the national defense.

src_legal: But neither communication nor publication is necessary to violate the subsection.
tgt_plain: But neither communication nor publication is necessary to violate the subsection.

src_legal: These include 42 U.S.C. §§ 2161 through 2166 relating to the authority of the Atomic Energy Commission to classify and declassify 'Restricted Data' ('Restricted Data' is a term of art employed uniquely by the Atomic Energy Act).
tgt_plain: These include 42 U.S.C. §§ 2161 through 2166 relating to the authority of the Atomic Energy Commission to classify and declassify 'Restricted Data' ('Restricted Data' is a special term used uniquely by the Atomic Energy Act).

src_legal: Title 42 U.S.C. § 2274, subsection (a), provides penalties for a person who 'communicates, transmits, or discloses (restricted data) * * * with intent to injure the United States or with intent to secure an advantage to any foreign nation * * *.' Subsection (b) of § 2274 provides lesser penalties for one who 'communicates, transmits, or discloses' such information 'with reason to believe such data will be utilized to injure the United States or to secure an advantage to any foreign nation * * *.' Other sections of Title 42 of the United States Code dealing with atomic energy prohibit and punish acquisition, removal, concealment, tampering with, alteration, mutilation, or destruction of documents incorporating 'Restricted Data' and provide penalties for employees and former employees of the Atomic Energy Commission, the armed services, contractors and licensees of the Atomic Energy Commission.
tgt_plain: Title 42 U.S.C. § 2274, subsection (a), provides penalties for a person who 'communicates, transmits, or discloses (restricted data) with intent to harm the United States or with intent to secure an advantage to any foreign nation.' Subsection (b) of § 2274 provides lesser penalties for one who 'communicates, transmits, or discloses' such information 'with reason to believe such data will be used to harm the United States or to secure an advantage to any foreign nation.' Other sections of Title 42 of the United States Code dealing with atomic energy ban and punish acquisition, removal, concealment, tampering with, change, destruction of documents including 'Restricted Data' and provide penalties for employees and former employees of the Atomic Energy Commission, the armed services, contractors and licensees of the Atomic Energy Commission.

src_legal: Title 50 U.S.C.App. § 781, 56 Stat. 390, prohibits the making of any sketch or other representation of military installations or any military equipment located on any military installation, as specified; and indeed Congress in the National Defense Act of 1940, 54 Stat. 676, as amended, 56 Stat. 179, conferred jurisdiction on federal district courts over civil actions 'to enjoin any violation' thereof. 50 U.S.C.App. § 1152(6).
tgt_plain: Title 50 U.S.C.App. § 781, 56 Stat. 390, bans the making of any sketch or other representation of military installations or any military equipment located on any military installation, as listed; and indeed Congress in the National Defense Act of 1940, 54 Stat. 676, as amended, 56 Stat. 179, gave power to federal district courts over civil actions 'to stop any violation' of it. 50 U.S.C.App. § 1152(6).

src_legal: Title 50 U.S.C. § 783(b) makes it unlawful for any officers or employees of the United States or any corporation which is owned by the United States to communicate material which has been 'classified' by the President to any person who that governmental employee knows or has reason to believe is an agent or representative of any foreign government or any Communist organization.
tgt_plain: Title 50 U.S.C. § 783(b) makes it illegal for any officers or employees of the United States or any corporation which is owned by the United States to communicate material which has been 'classified' by the President to any person who that government employee knows or has reason to believe is an agent or representative of any foreign government or any Communist organization.

src_legal: Interestingly the Times explained its refusal to allow the Government to examine its own purloined documents by saying in substance this might compromise its sources and informants! tgt_plain: Interestingly the Times explained its refusal to allow the Government to examine its own stolen documents by saying in substance this might compromise its sources and informants! The Times thus claims a right to protect the secrecy of its sources while denying that the Government of the United States has that power.

src_legal: With respect to the question of inherent power of the Executive to classify papers, records, and documents as secret, or otherwise unavailable for public exposure, and to secure aid of the courts for enforcement, there may be an analogy with respect to this Court.
tgt_plain: With respect to the question of natural power of the Executive to classify papers, records, and documents as secret, or otherwise unavailable for public exposure, and to secure help of the courts for enforcement, there may be a comparison with respect to this Court.

src_legal: No statute gives this Court express power to establish and enforce the utmost security measures for the secrecy of our deliberations and records.
tgt_plain: No law gives this Court express power to establish and enforce the highest security measures for the secrecy of our discussions and records.

src_legal: Appellee, Walker-Thomas Furniture Company, operates a retail furniture store in the District of Columbia.
tgt_plain: Appellee, Walker-Thomas Furniture Company, operates a retail furniture store in the District of Columbia.

src_legal: During the period from 1957 to 1962 each appellant in these cases purchased a number of household items from Walker-Thomas, for which payment was to be made in installments.
tgt_plain: During the period from 1957 to 1962 each appellant in these cases purchased a number of household items from Walker-Thomas, for which payment was to be made in installments.

src_legal: The terms of each purchase were contained in a printed form contract which set forth the value of the purchased item and purported to lease the item to appellant for a stipulated monthly rent payment.
tgt_plain: The terms of each purchase were contained in a printed form contract which stated the value of the purchased item and claimed to lease the item to appellant for a specified monthly rent payment.

src_legal: The contract then provided, in substance, that title would remain in Walker-Thomas until the total of all the monthly payments made equaled the stated value of the item, at which time appellants could take title.
tgt_plain: The contract then provided, in substance, that ownership would remain with Walker-Thomas until the total of all the monthly payments made equaled the stated value of the item, at which time appellants could take ownership.

src_legal: On May 12, 1962, appellant Thorne purchased an item described as a Daveno, three tables, and two lamps, having total stated value of $391.10.
tgt_plain: On May 12, 1962, appellant Thorne purchased an item described as a Daveno, three tables, and two lamps, having total stated value of $391.10.

src_legal: Shortly thereafter, he defaulted on his monthly payments and appellee sought to replevy all the items purchased since the first transaction in 1958.
tgt_plain: Shortly after, he failed to make his monthly payments and appellee sought to take back all the items purchased since the first transaction in 1958.

src_legal: Similarly, on April 17, 1962, appellant Williams bought a stereo set of stated value of $514.95.1 She too defaulted shortly thereafter, and appellee sought to replevy all the items purchased since December, 1957.
tgt_plain: Similarly, on April 17, 1962, appellant Williams bought a stereo set of stated value of $514.95. She too failed to make payments shortly after, and appellee sought to take back all the items purchased since December, 1957.

src_legal: In other jurisdictions, it has been held as a matter of common law that unconscionable contracts are not enforceable.2 While no decision of this court so holding has been found, the notion that an unconscionable bargain should not be given full enforcement is by no means novel.

src_legal: In fact, in view of the absence of prior authority on the point, we consider the congressional adoption of § 2-302 persuasive authority for following the rationale of the cases from which the section is explicitly derived.5 Accordingly, we hold that where the element of unconscionability is present at the time a contract is made, the contract should not be enforced.
tgt_plain: In fact, in view of the lack of earlier authority on the point, we consider the congressional adoption of § 2-302 persuasive authority for following the reasoning of the cases from which the section is clearly derived. Accordingly, we hold that where the element of unconscionability is present at the time a contract is made, the contract should not be enforced.

src_legal: Unconscionability has generally been recognized to include an absence of meaningful choice on the part of one of the parties together with contract terms which are unreasonably favorable to the other party.6 Whether a meaningful choice is present in a particular case can only be determined by consideration of all the circumstances surrounding the transaction.
tgt_plain: Unconscionability has generally been recognized to include a lack of meaningful choice on the part of one of the parties together with contract terms which are unreasonably favorable to the other party. Whether a meaningful choice is present in a particular case can only be determined by considering all the circumstances surrounding the transaction.

src_legal: In many cases the meaningfulness of the choice is negated by a gross inequality of bargaining power.7 The manner in which the contract was entered is also relevant to this consideration.
tgt_plain: In many cases the meaningfulness of the choice is canceled by a gross inequality of bargaining power. The manner in which the contract was entered is also relevant to this consideration.

src_legal: Did each party to the contract, considering his obvious education or lack of it, have a reasonable opportunity to understand the terms of the contract, or were the important terms hidden in a maze of fine print and minimized by deceptive sales practices? Ordinarily, one who signs an agreement without full knowledge of its terms might be held to assume the risk that he has entered a one-sided bargain.8 But when a party of little bargaining power, and hence little real choice, signs a commercially unreasonable contract with little or no knowledge of its terms, it is hardly likely that his consent, or even an objective manifestation of his consent, was ever given to all the terms.
tgt_plain: Did each party to the contract, considering his obvious education or lack of it, have a reasonable opportunity to understand the terms of the contract, or were the important terms hidden in a maze of fine print and minimized by misleading sales practices? Ordinarily, one who signs an agreement without full knowledge of its terms might be held to assume the risk that he has entered a one-sided bargain. src_legal: Justice Holmes, while sitting on the Supreme Judicial Court of Massachusetts, made this observation:.
tgt_plain: Justice Holmes, while serving on the Supreme Judicial Court of Massachusetts, made this observation.

src_legal: When two people make a contract, they create new law for themselves, new rights and duties that supplement or modify whatever entitlements they already possess.
tgt_plain: When two people make a contract, they create new law for themselves, new rights and duties that add to or modify whatever rights they already possess.

src_legal: The law of contracts facilitates this process and may therefore aptly be described as an instrument of decentralized lawmaking.[1] There are, of course, limits to the lawmaking powers that private parties enjoy.
tgt_plain: The law of contracts helps this process and may therefore properly be described as a tool of decentralized lawmaking. There are, of course, limits to the lawmaking powers that private parties enjoy.

src_legal: Within these constraints, however, contracting parties enjoy a legislative preeminence: the rules they must follow are fixed by the terms of their own agreement and it is to the agreement that a court will look in deciding whether each has given or done all he should.
tgt_plain: Within these limits, however, contracting parties enjoy a legislative priority: the rules they must follow are set by the terms of their own agreement and it is to the agreement that a court will look in deciding whether each has given or done all he should.

src_legal: But even if an agreement is acknowledged to fall within the limits of permissible private lawmaking, its scope and the meaning of its terms may be uncertain.
tgt_plain: But even if an agreement is recognized to fall within the limits of allowed private lawmaking, its scope and the meaning of its terms may be uncertain.

src_legal: It may be unclear what the parties have agreed to, and where this is the case, even the least interventionist court must resolve a preliminary issue of interpretation before it can enforce the agreement according to its terms.
tgt_plain: It may be unclear what the parties have agreed to, and where this is the case, even the least interfering court must resolve a preliminary issue of interpretation before it can enforce the agreement according to its terms.

src_legal: The first solution clearly requires an interpretive elaboration of the parties' bargain, typically through the implication of a risk-allocating term the court believes the parties themselves would have accepted had they addressed the matter at hand.
tgt_plain: The first solution clearly requires an interpretive expansion of the parties' bargain, typically through the suggestion of a risk-allocating term the court believes the parties themselves would have accepted had they addressed the matter at hand.

src_legal: If, for example, the parties have included an ambiguous term in their agreement it may be necessary for the court to decide which of the term's several meanings to adopt.
tgt_plain: If, for example, the parties have included an unclear term in their agreement it may be necessary for the court to decide which of the term's several meanings to adopt.

src_legal: When are prior statements and promises to be deemed an integral part of the bargain and when should we assume that the parties meant to deny them legal effect through a calculated act of silence or exclusion? A. number of interpretive rules have been devised to help answer this question; often described collectively as the parol evidence rule, they are the subject of the present chapter.
tgt_plain: When are earlier statements and promises to be considered an integral part of the bargain and when should we assume that the parties meant to deny them legal effect through a deliberate act of silence or exclusion? A number of interpretive rules have been created to help answer this question; often described collectively as the parol evidence rule, they are the subject of the present chapter.

src_legal: When two parties have made a contract and have expressed it in a writing to which they have both assented as the complete and accurate integration of that contract, evidence, whether parol or otherwise, of antecedent understandings and negotiations will  not be admitted for the purpose of varying or contradicting the writing.[5].
tgt_plain: When two parties have made a contract and have expressed it in a writing to which they have both agreed as the complete and accurate final version of that contract, evidence, whether oral or otherwise, of earlier understandings and negotiations will not be admitted for the purpose of changing or contradicting the writing.

src_legal: Indeed, even its name is a deception for the parol evidence rule is not, properly speaking, a rule of evidence at all, nor is its application limited to parol (as distinct from written) agreements.
tgt_plain: Indeed, even its name is misleading for the parol evidence rule is not, properly speaking, a rule of evidence at all, nor is its application limited to oral (as distinct from written) agreements.

src_legal: The rationale for the parol evidence rule was stated, with Elizabethan eloquence, in the Countess of Rutland Case, 5 Co. 26a, 77 Eng.
tgt_plain: The reasoning for the parol evidence rule was stated, with Elizabethan eloquence, in the Countess of Rutland Case, 5 Co. 26a, 77 Eng.

src_legal: that matters in writing made by advice and on consideration, and which finally import the certain truth of the agreement of the parties should be controlled by averment of the parties to be proved by the uncertain testimony of slippery memory.
tgt_plain: that matters in writing made with advice and with consideration, and which finally show the certain truth of the agreement of the parties should be controlled by claims of the parties to be proved by the uncertain testimony of unreliable memory.

src_legal: Since the days of Chief Justice Popham, if not earlier, the parol evidence rule has been defended as a device to preserve the security of transactions.
tgt_plain: Since the days of Chief Justice Popham, if not earlier, the parol evidence rule has been defended as a tool to preserve the security of transactions.

src_legal: Absent fraud or mistake, the court declared, the negotiations preceding the written contract were not its concern.
tgt_plain: Without fraud or mistake, the court declared, the negotiations before the written contract were not its concern.

src_legal: Were it otherwise, written contracts would be enforced not according to the plain effect of their language, but pursuant to the story of their negotiations as told by the litigant having at the time being the greater power of persuading the trier of fact.
tgt_plain: If it were otherwise, written contracts would be enforced not according to the plain effect of their language, but according to the story of their negotiations as told by the party having at the time the greater power of persuading the judge or jury.

src_legal: So far as contracts are concerned, the rule of law would give way to the mere notions of man as to who should win law suits. [Without the parol evidence rule] there would be no assurance of the enforceability of a written contract.
tgt_plain: As far as contracts are concerned, the rule of law would give way to the mere ideas of people about who should win lawsuits. Without the parol evidence rule there would be no assurance of the enforceability of a written contract.

src_legal: If such assurance were removed today from our law, general disaster would result because of the consequent destruction of confidence, for the tremendous but closely adjusted machinery of modern business cannot function at all without confidence in the enforceability of contracts.[7].
tgt_plain: If such assurance were removed today from our law, general disaster would result because of the resulting destruction of confidence, for the tremendous but closely adjusted machinery of modern business cannot function at all without confidence in the enforceability of contracts.

src_legal: The modern history of the parol evidence rule has been marked by a growing appreciation of the consequences of this last observation and its implications for our view not only of the rule but of contract interpretation in general.
tgt_plain: The modern history of the parol evidence rule has been marked by a growing understanding of the consequences of this last observation and its implications for our view not only of the rule but of contract interpretation in general.

src_legal: The parol evidence rule bars the proof of prior agreements where the parties have embodied their contract in a writing that is meant to be a complete and accurate statement of its terms.
tgt_plain: The parol evidence rule blocks the proof of earlier agreements where the parties have put their contract in a writing that is meant to be a complete and accurate statement of its terms.

src_legal: Application of the rule in any particular case clearly requires, therefore, a preliminary judgment concerning the parties' intentions with regard to the writing itself: did they mean it to be an exclusive source of contractual liability or something less than this, a partial statement of the terms of their agreement requiring supplementation from other sources? To determine what the writing means, or meant, to the parties, it must be viewed against the background of their attitudes and expectations, and while the writing serves an important evidentiary function in the reconstruction of this background, it cannot provide its own interpretive framework (any more than a literary text can criticize itself).
tgt_plain: Use of the rule in any particular case clearly requires, therefore, a preliminary judgment concerning the parties' intentions with regard to the writing itself: did they mean it to be an exclusive source of contractual responsibility or something less than this, a partial statement of the terms of their agreement requiring addition from other sources? To determine what the writing means, or meant, to the parties, it must be viewed against the background of their attitudes and expectations, and while the writing serves an important evidentiary function in the rebuilding of this background, it cannot provide its own interpretive framework (any more than a literary text can criticize itself).

src_legal: An object is never the same as a person's attitude toward it, though the object may provide evidence as to what that attitude is and help to make it interpretively accessible to us.
tgt_plain: An object is never the same as a person's attitude toward it, though the object may provide evidence about what that attitude is and help to make it understandable to us.

src_legal: But to say that a writing can never be more than evidence of the parties' intentions is not to say that all writings should be treated equally: some provide better evidence of the parties' intentions than others do, and should be given greater weight in the court's interpretive deliberations.
tgt_plain: But to say that a writing can never be more than evidence of the parties' intentions is not to say that all writings should be treated equally: some provide better evidence of the parties' intentions than others do, and should be given greater importance in the court's interpretive thinking.

src_legal: Where it seems obvious from an inspection of the writing that the parties did in fact assent to it as an integrated statement of their agreement, it may seem like a metaphysical quibble to insist that a writing can only have greater or lesser evidentiary weight and can never be self- validating.
tgt_plain: Where it seems obvious from an examination of the writing that the parties did in fact agree to it as an integrated statement of their agreement, it may seem like a philosophical minor point to insist that a writing can only have greater or lesser evidentiary weight and can never be self-validating.

src_legal: But quibbles of this sort, though of seemingly little practical consequence, can help us to a deeper philosophical understanding of the law and to a more realistic appraisal of its rules.
tgt_plain: But minor points of this sort, though of seemingly little practical consequence, can help us to a deeper philosophical understanding of the law and to a more realistic assessment of its rules.

src_legal: It is argued that on May 30, 1942, the date the petitioner was charged with remaining in the prohibited area, there were conflicting orders outstanding, forbidding him both to leave the area and to remain there.
tgt_plain: It is argued that on May 30, 1942, the date the petitioner was charged with remaining in the banned area, there were conflicting orders in effect, forbidding him both to leave the area and to remain there.

src_legal: There was an order issued March 27, 1942, which prohibited petitioner and others of Japanese ancestry from leaving the area, but its effect was specifically limited in time 'until and to the extent that a future proclamation or order should so permit or direct.' 7 Fed.Reg. 2601.
tgt_plain: There was an order issued March 27, 1942, which banned petitioner and others of Japanese ancestry from leaving the area, but its effect was specifically limited in time 'until and to the extent that a future announcement or order should so allow or direct.' 7 Fed.Reg. 2601.

src_legal: That 'future order', the one for violation of which petitioner was convicted, was issued May 3, 1942, and it did 'direct' exclusion from the area of all persons of Japanese ancestry, before 12 o'clock noon, May 9; furthermore it contained a warning that all such persons found in the prohibited area would be liable to punishment under the March 21, 1942 Act of Congress.
tgt_plain: That 'future order', the one for violation of which petitioner was convicted, was issued May 3, 1942, and it did 'order' exclusion from the area of all persons of Japanese ancestry, before 12 o'clock noon, May 9; furthermore it contained a warning that all such persons found in the banned area would be subject to punishment under the March 21, 1942 Act of Congress.

src_legal: Consequently, the only order in effect touching the petitioner's being in the area on May 30, 1942, the date specified in the information against him, was the May 3 order which prohibited his remaining there, and it was that same order, which he stipulated in his trial that he had violated, knowing of its existence.
tgt_plain: Consequently, the only order in effect concerning the petitioner's being in the area on May 30, 1942, the date specified in the charging document against him, was the May 3 order which banned his remaining there, and it was that same order, which he agreed in his trial that he had violated, knowing of its existence.
